SummaryOfEvents:
On 28 December 2008 while stowing nets on a flying bridge at the aft end of the ship, a crew member leaned or fell against the guardrail and toppled into the sea.  After numerous attempts to assist him and a delay of approximately 95 minutes, the crew member‘s body was recovered from the water. No vital signs were apparent and it was presumed that he was dead

Approximate location of the casualty was at latitude: 49° 14’N, Longitude: 11° 36’W in international waters.

At 22.00 hours LT/24th December: After dismissed departure station, P/M and ABB sighted missing crew member (Mess Boy) on B deck passageway in  accommodation.

07. 45-08. 25 hours LT/25th Dec: Re-searched crew’s accommodation and investigation made by master.

At 18 :15 hours on 24 December 2008, the Australian registered floating storage and offloading tanker, Karratha Spirit, began disconnecting from its mooring buoy at the Legendre Oil Field, about 60 miles north of Dampier, Western Australia, because of an approaching tropical cyclone.
The Master was on the forecastle, directly controlling the operation. Before the mooring hawsers could be released from the ship, the import hose drifted under the hawsers and he ordered the main engine to be run astern for about 1 minute in an attempt to pull the hose clear. At about 19:54 hours, after the wire suspending the oil import hose parted suddenly, the mater ordered the crew to finish letting go the hawser pickup lines so that the ship could depart the mooring buoy.

An integrated rating applied the port winch drum’s brake to stop the drum moving and then stepped between the cheeks of the drum to cut the lashing that held the end of the heavy hawser pick line on the drum. 
At about 19:58 hours, when the lashing parted, the last three turns of heavy line rapidly unwound from the drum, striking the rating on the head and throwing him under the winch drum. He died as result of his injuries.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents:
At around 15:15 hours on 18 September 2008 the five metre glass fibre angling boat BARBARA MARY left  the slip at Kilkee, Co Clare. Fifteen minutes later, the ship capsized when it hit a large wave. A retired fisherman from Kilkee was thrown into the water and drowned. The owner of the boat was trapped under the hull and rescued by the Kilkee Rescue Service a short time later.

The fisherman's body was recovered on 21 September 2008 by local divers carrying out a search in conjunction with Garda and  Naval Service divers

At about 09:52 hours, an explosion occurred on board the fishing ship Gertje Bruhns at the port of Ditzum. The ship was moored at her berth.

The explosion took place in the ship's steering gear compartment, where the deckhand was carrying out painting work. As a preparatory measure, he cleaned the surfaces with a degreasing agent. The resulting vapour led to the formation of an explosive gas-air mixture. The automatic start-up of the diesel heater in the same area ignited the mixture. The deckhand was severely injured by the explosion and had to be treated in a specialist clinic. The ship was only marginally damaged by the explosion and small fire that followed.
Consequences1: Serious injuries,Ship remains fit to proceed

SOLASStatus: CAPT. HENRY JACKMAN: Unknown/unspecified, QUEBECOIS: Unknown/unspecified
Location: Beauharnois Canal,  Saint Lawrence  Seaway, Quebec
SummaryOfEvents: At approximately 04:31 hours Eastern Standard Time on 17 December 2008, in darkness and reduced visibility due to snow, the upbound bulk carrier Québecois and the downbound bulk carrier Capt. Henry Jackman collided during a meeting situation in the Beauharnois Canal, near the port of Valleyfield, Quebec. Both vessels were able to proceed to their respective destinations. No injuries, structural damage, or pollution, were reported.

On the evening of 16 December 2008, the Dutch cargo ship Freya put out of the Hamburg port heading to sea. The next port of call was Oslo, Norway. The ship's command and an apprentice were on the bridge, both citizens of the Netherlands. The Freya was exempt from the obligation to accept a pilot. Navigation was on the basis of the nautical chart was not in operation. The ship was operated in the autopilot mode. The two radar systems were operated in North up, relative mode.
The weather conditions were good. The wind blew from the south at 3 Bft and it was cloudy, but there was no rainfall. As the Freya reached the Elbe approach at 22:00 hours, there was an Ebb stream of about 2 Kts. The voyage speed of Freya was 18 Kts over ground.

As the Freya passed the light buoy 24 at the location of Gelbsand, preparations were made for the next course alteration to port. At t this moment a lighted cardinal buoy had been spotted for the first time on the portside ahead. The buoy was one of two south-cardinal buoys that secured a construction area for building the Gelbsand leading light outside the fairway at the location of the light buoy 22. A restricted area had been set up around the construction area. Freya's command did not see any indication of the construction area on the nautical chart, because the corresponding official chart correction was not yet available on board.

Freya was called by the Vessel Traffic Service (VTS) Cuxhaven using VHF and was requested to execute a "hard to port" manoeuvre. At the conning position on the bridge, a switchover to manual control was then made, the rate of speed reduced and a "hard to port" executed. Meanwhile, the VTS lade further calls. At 22:16 hours, the Freya collided with the front light structure. The cargo ship was severely damaged. Water entered the forepeak. Nevertheless the ship was able to anchor in the Neuwerk roads without needing any support.

Nobody was injured and no substances hazardous to the environment were released due to this marine accident

MIRABELLE grounded at low speed shortly after departure from the port of Svendborg. The vessel was fully loaded with a draft of 6.4 m, which was close to  the depth of water at several positions on the ships route. The master was alone on the bridge and occupied with steering and navigating in the narrow area and handling of the search light looking for dark buoys. Although the master was not familiar in the area he did not use a pilot.
During high water and change of current the vessel refloated on 18 December at 0225 and returned to Svendborg. There was found no damage to the vessel.

At 20.31 hours LT on 13th December 2008 the roro cargo ship ROPAX I dragged anchor and made contact with the single point mooring off Algeciras, Spain.  The vessel sustained two holes below the waterline, and the SPM was slightly damaged, but remained operational.

During adverse weather conditions, on 13th December 2008, the anchor of the container ship APL SYDNEY  came into contact with a submarine gas pipeline. The ship's windlass became inoperative, the pipeline ruptured and was isolated soon after. The anchor cable was cut and two shackles and the anchor left on the sea-bed. There were no injuries.

SOLASStatus: NORDIC DIANA: SOLAS, RMS SAIMAA: SOLAS
SummaryOfEvents:
The RMS Saimaa  was sailing  from Duisburg to Jontseno (Finland). On 12 December 2008, the ship reached the Brunsbütel lock. At 09:24 hours, the eastward canal passage began as a Traffic Group (VG) 3 ship with pilot advice.

Due to a collective call at 09:19 hours as well as the AIS data which had been received, the ship's command was aware that the OOCL Finland and the Haldoz were approaching on the section between the inland port and the Kudensee siding area. On reaching the Ostermoor ferry, visibility reportedly dropped to 200 m. Therefore the speed was reduced to about 7 kts. Immediately after passing the Ostermoor ferry, visibility reportedly deteriorated to 100m. The oncoming OOCL Finland was passed safely off the port boundary and then shortly afterwards also the Haldoz.
The ship's command then reportedly noticed that the RMS Saimaa turned to port and accordingly her stern neared to the southern embankment. The initiated rudder and engine manoeuvres prevented contact with the canal embankments. Finally, the RMS Saimaa was positioned at an angle to about 20° approximately 15 m away from the northern embankment with virtually no speed through water. The bow was reportedly positioned well north of the canal axis.

The Nordic Diana was sailing from Halla (Finland) to Newport (United Kingdom). She passed westward through the Kiel Canal (NOK) on 12 December 2008 as a VG 3 with pilot advice. 
The Kudensee siding area was passed at 09:34 hours. Visibility had reportedly   been fluctuating sporadically, but reportedly dropped to about 100 m at canal kilometre (ckm) 7.0.
At about 09:46 hours, the pilot on the RMS Saimaa called the pilot on the Nordic Diana by VHF. He was situated under the Brunshbüttel viaduct and requested that both ships pass port-by-port. The RMS Saimaa was reportedly not identifiable on the radar of the Nordic Diana.  The pilot on the Nordic Diana complied with the requested pass. Following that, he reportedly advised the chief officer, who was at the helm, to steer to starboard further still in order to provide the RMS Saimaa with as much room as possible. At that point, the speed of the ship was reportedly not reduced as they were concerns that the steer ability may then be lost.
When the RMS Saimaa became visible on the Nordic Diana's radar unit after passing under the viaduct, the pilot reportedly realised that the agreed port-by-port pass was not possible. Despite all countermeasures, the collision was unavoidable. 
Due to the collision, The Nordic Diana moved towards the southern embankment. However, an astern manoeuvre and appropriate rudder manoeuvre enabled the ship to be positioned lengthways on the canal again. 
The two ships were subsequently inspected for damage. There were no injuries. Water ingress was detected in the forepeak and in the bow thruster room on board the RMS Saimaa. The bow thruster was reportedly no longer operable. The Master gave orders for the areas to be pumped out. The RMS Saimaa remained afloat and was manoeuvrable. 
After consultation with the VTS, the two ships sailed to Brunsbüttel under their own steam

On 9th December 2009 the bunkering tanker  Skorpion was proceeding from Paljassaare harbour to Port Muuga. At 05.35 hours the ship began berthing operations, starboard side.  At 05.40 hours there was a blackout aboard ship, resulting in steering loss. The propeller blades automatically resumed the position "full astern“ and the ship’s aft end  came into contact with the shore, which had been strengthened by limestone, while her bridge was in contact with the quay.  Ship’s propeller and the hull, aft end, were damaged. There was also damage to the  quay. At 18.28 the ship berthed, being assisted by a tug.

On 8th December 2008 "Finnmaster", a Ro-Ro ferry, was transiting the Kiel Canal when it suffered a main engine crankcase explosion.  In order to keep the canal free for navigation the vessel had to move sideways and in doing so it touched the bottom of the canal at about 22.29 hours LT.  The vessel was taken to the safe refuge of the port of Kiel where a diver's survey was carried out.  
The survey found no damage other than small areas of abrasion to the anti-fouling paint.
The subsequent investigation into the cause of the crankcase explosion found that there was a gas blow past one of the pistons causing over pressurisation of the crankcase.  Vapour was released but there was no fire nor any injuries.

In the early hours of 5th December 2008, ten people set off from Colla Pier near Schull, Co.cork in an open boat (with sealed deck) powered by a 30 HP outboat engine to spend the weekend on Coney Island, which lies about one kilometre off the coast  of Cork, in the South west of Ireland. 
Shortly afterwards the boat capsized resulting in the death of one man.
The post mortem found that the man died as result of acute cardio-respiratory failure and drowning associated with hypothermia.

On 4th December 2008 the cargo ship NICOLE C was entering a tidal port located in an estuary in the eastern region of the UK. On final approaches to the berth the bow encountered an area of decreased under keel clearance, which resulted in the port quarter of the vessel swinging to port. This was further aggravated by the effect of the left hand propeller as the vessel was operating astern propulsion. 
Despite rapid actions by the master and pilot to put the rudder hard to port and kick the engines ahead, the port quarter came into contact with an unfendered concrete knuckle at the end of the berth. This resulted in the vessel sustaining an indentation and small fracture to the shell  plating.
Subsequent inspection by class and the MCA required the vessel to be repaired before proceeding to sea.

Se establece contacto con buque en cercanía.

Le 03 Décembre 2008, le thonier-congélateur Le Titan, battant pavillon français appartenant à la société SAPMER, prolonge son escale commerciale à Port Victoria, Mahé (Seychelles) après débarquement de la pêche, pour effectuer des travaux.

Des problèmes d'étanchéité des vannes des collecteurs de sortie d'ammoniac des évaporateurs de l'installation frigorifique, compromettant  la descente et le maintien du froid dans les cuves de conservation  des prises et donc l'exploitation commerciale, et pouvant affecter également la sécurité, ont rendu nécessaire la réalisation de travaux dans les meilleurs délais.  

Cette importante opération est réalisée par une entreprise seychelloise et des membres de l'équipage. Elle est en cours d'achèvement lorsque, vers 16:00 heures locales, une important  fuite d'ammoniac se produit dans le tunnel de l'installation frigorifique, sous le pont principal entre les cuves à poisson où travaillent employé de l'entreprise et marins.

Malgré l'intervention rapide des secours, conduite par des membres de l'équipage et les sapeurs pompiers de Port Victoria, l'accident fait dix victimes dont six décédées.

Les enquêteurs on pu rencontrer le capitaine et les membres de l'équipage présents à bord au moment de l'accident. Ils ont pu s'entretenir avec les sapeurs pompiers, le commandant de port, le responsable de la sécurité portuaire et son adjoint. 

Ils ont visité le navire au cours de son escale à Port Louis (Iles Maurice) du 18 Janvier au 02 Février 2009. A cette occasion, ils ont pu avoir des entretiens complémentaires avec des membres de l'équipage et rencontrer des représentants du Chantiers Naval de l'Océan Indien (CNOI), qui a achevé les travaux  après l'accident.

Location: Baltic sea, 3 nm from port of Liepaja
SummaryOfEvents: On December 2, 2008, the fishing vessel BEVERINA capsized and foundered in the Baltic sea 3 nautical miles from the port of Liepaja. Six crew members drowned.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
Vers minuit, dans la  nuit du 1er au 2 Décembre 2008, le navire de pêche Emmanuelle-Jean  appareille du port de Granville avec 3 hommes d'équipage, pour se rendre sur sa zone de pêche située en baie de Saint-Malo. Il est armé à la coquille Saint-Jaques.

Le 02 Décembre à 08:10 heures, le navire met ses dragues à l'eau. Quinze minutes plus tard, celles-ci sont remontées pour être vidées sur le pont.

Le navire de pêche Carpe Diem, immatriculé à Cherbourg, en pêche dans le même secteur, aperçoit, à 08:37 heures, un navire retourné à environ un demi mille. Il prévient aussitôt le CROSS Corsen qui met en œuvre  des moyens  de recherche et de sauvetage. Cinq navires de pêche sont à proximité et se dirigent vers la coque retournée.

Les 3 membres d'équipage de l'Emmanuelle-Jean sont récupérés peu après par les navires de pêche qui font aussitôt route sur Saint-Malo. Ils sont pris en charge par les sapeurs-pompiers dès leur arrivée à quai.

Un des matelots, en arrêt cardiaque, ne peut être ramené à la vie, malgré les tentatives de réanimation pratiquées, tant à bord d'un chalutier que par les membres du service de secours. En hypothermie, les 2 autres sont hospitalisés à Saint Malo.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship rendered unfit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents: At 20.49 hours LT on 1st December 2008 two dry cargo vessels, the HAGLAND BONA and the BLUEBIRD, collided in a very narrow dredged channel. The vessels had agreed to pass port to port and also agreed to a meeting point in the channel. Close to the agreed meeting point one the HAGLAND BONA experienced interaction with the seafloor, and therefore lost steering. She was unable to maintain her position in the channel, and the two vessels collided, hitting each other on both vessels' port bows. The HAGLAND BONA subsequently ran aground. The other, inbound, vessel, the BLUEBIRD  was able to continue by her own power to the destination harbour. Only steel damages to both vessels. There were no injuries and no pollution.

Le cap blanc, caboteur roulier, effectue, le 1 décembre 2008, dans le port d'Argentia (Baie de Placentia, Terre-Neuve) un chargement en pontée de sacs de sel de déneigement. Il appareille en fin de matinée à destination de St-Pierre. La traversée dure généralement moins de douze heures selon les conditions météo. Après avoir satisfait aux premières obligations de compte-rendu auprès de la station de Placentia Radio, le navire manque le rendez-vous suivant, prévu vers 21:10 heures et ne répond pas à l'appel de la station, lancé à 21:27 heures. A ce moment, il se trouve hors de portée du récepteur terrestre A.I.S. situé à Placentia.

Au cours des heures qui suivent, le navire fait l'objet d'appels systématiques et réguliers de la part  de stations maritimes et terrestres, en utilisant l'ensemble des moyens de communication présents à bord. Un navire de la garde côtière canadienne est dérouté vers la zone où est supposé se trouver le Cap Blanc.

Un premier message d'alerte est diffusé le 2 décembre 2008 à 07:08 heures. A partir de 08:37 heures, différents moyens d'intervention nautiques sont dépêchés sur zone et le navire est retrouvé à 10:54 heures, chaviré, flottant quille en l'air au large de l'Ile de Burin (prequ'île de Burin) à environ trois milles de la côte.

La présence de survivant à l'intérieur de la coque est confirmée à 11:39 heures. Le navire coule à 14:08 heures par une profondeur de 130 mètres.

Une investigation ultérieure de l'épave permettra de retrouver le corps de trois des quatre marins présents à bord et d'opérer à cette occasion un certain nombre de prises de vues à l'extérieur et à l'intérieur du navire.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
At 01.50 hours LT on 29th November 2008 the cable laying vessel WAVE VENTURE had her dynamic positioning system engaged and was grappling for a submarine cable.  The DP desk reported the loss of 3 out of 5 thrusters (1, 4 and 5).  Engine room was advised.  Around 15 minutes later fire alarm sounded indicating fire in the generator room.  The master decided to release CO2 -   However, a watertight door between the generator room and main engine room had to be closed manually and though an attempt was made to close this door it was abandoned.  The Co2 was released.  Instead of the 21 bottles being released, all the 34 bottles in the bank were released.  Fire was extinguished successfully.

The cause of alternator failure was a failed non drive end bearing on the alternator of one generator set (No. 6).  Smoke was seen coming out of the generator space 15 minutes before the fire alarm sounded.  Although the watch keeping engineer was in the engine control room which was 10 m away from the generator room he did not recognise that an alternator had failed catastrophically; tripped off the main switch board causing the thrusters to power off; broke the turbochargers foundation and ruptured lubricating oil pipes spraying oil onto the by now exposed alternator causing the fire to break out.  The engine continued to run and by the time he had diagnosed the situation, the engineer on watch could not enter the room to activate the emergency stop.  Eventually the engine was stopped from the emergency generator room.  The generator engines on this vessel had a history of similar failures and the makers have been unable to pinpoint the cause of the problem.

On 26 November 2008 the skipper of the  fishing boat ENTERPRISE II  was using the engine in the astern mode which inadvertently  caused the  propeller shaft to withdraw from the gearbox. This damaged the stern tube which allowed water ingress.  Without manoeuvrability the poor weather conditions caused the vessel to drift ashore and ground.  The vessel did not suffer a breach of the hull from grounding.

On 26th November 2009 the general cargo ship DAN VIKING was in route T when her rudder became stuck and could only be moved on her starboard side. The vessel abandoned route T for anchorage. Tug assistance was arranged and the vessel was towed to Delfzijl.

On 24th November 2008 the container ship SPIRIT OF ESPERANCE was in dock at Townsville. At 21.19 hours LT, a worker fell down whilst working to secure a cargo crane hook, and sustained serious injuries. He was hospitalised soon after the incident, but his injuries proved fatal.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

SOLASStatus: HMS WESTMINSTER: Unknown/unspecified, PRINCESS ROSE: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents:
On 24 November 2008, a royal naval officer fell into the River Thames at Gravesend Reach when transferring from the frigate HMS Westminster to the class V passenger ship Princess Rose. The ships were making way at a speed of a speed of 4 knots. The officer was quickly recovered by the Gravesend lifeboat, which was following the two ships. She was then taken ashore, where she was treated by paramedics.

The officer was climbing down the pilot ladder when the painter connecting Princess Rose to the warship parted. As the passenger ship drifted away from transfer position, the lower rungs of the ladder became trapped in the boarding access. Consequently, the bottom of the ladder was pulled away from the warship's side to an angle of about 40° until its lower spreader gave way under the increasing tension. As the bottom of the ladder ran free, the officer fell off and, although she managed to momentarily hold on to a manrope, she soon lost her grip and fell into the water

At about 02.30 hours LT on 24th November 2008, the long-liner fishing vessel CANTARA began to shoot her fishing lines and baited hooks onto the sea bed in 200m depth of water. While shooting the lines through the aft hatchway from inside the shelter deck, the two end-of-line dhan buoys and a heavy marker buoy had been prepared to be launched into the sea by two deckhands from the open deck above. A 15m line was connected between the marker buoy and the dhan buoys. The dhan buoys were also attached to one end of a 300m riser line, which passed through the hatchway and was stowed in a shelter deck bin.
When the fishing line had been shot, the vessel was stopped so that three heavy weights, which were attached to the other end of the 300m riser, could be launched into the sea. The vessel then moved forward again allowing the riser line to pass through the hatchway. When the riser line was nearly all out, one of the deckhands threw the dhan buoys over the side, and, as the connecting rope paid out, the second deckhand released the marker buoy. Suddenly, the second deckhand was lifted up and thrown over the metre-high bulwark. The first deckhand shouted to the shelter deck crew, who saw the first deckhand land in the water on his back. He made no attempt to swim to the buoys and he was quickly lost from sight. The marker buoy was then picked up to see if the deckhand had become entangled in the line - he was not. The skipper broadcast a PANPAN message on VHF channel 16, which was received by a nearby fishing vessel.  He also attempted to send a Digital Selective Calling alert on medium frequency, the latter which was not received by the local coastguard station. However, the coastguard was later informed and a large search ensued but the deckhand was not found.

continued to take in water, and RCC decided to evacuate the crew to ensure their safety.
Evacuation was completed at 08.30 without any personal injuries. Oil-spill response resources
were soon in place, and the environmental consequences of the incident were minimal.

Following heavy weather damage in the English Channel on 10 November 2008 (see GSIS Ref No - C0007193) the MAERSK NEWPORT continued her passage to Algeciras for repairs. 
Repairs were arranged by the technical superintendent with little input from the ship's crew.  Unbeknown to the crew, oxy/acetylene metal cutting by shore contractors had been arranged for when the ship was alongside and engaged in cargo operations.  At about 00.55 hours LT on 15 November, the contractor's safety watchman left the forecastle and, by 01.10 hours LT a fire had developed in the vicinity of the port windlass winch mooring rope and a bank of 15 acetylene bottles.  One oxygen and two acetylene bottles exploded in the fire, which was extinguished at 05.46 hours LT.  There were no injuries.  Damage was restricted to the forecastle area.  The cause of the fire is likely to have been a discarded cigarette which ignited contractors' clothing in the vicinity of the mooring rope and acetylene hoses.
Because of poor communications no hot work Permit to Work control measures were in place and the contractor's safety watchman had no emergency communication link with the crew.  He left his safety station without the knowledge of the foreman and so the fire was not discovered for about 15 minutes.  The gas cutting assemblies were not leak tested and the "in use" gas bottles were co-located with the remaining bottles increasing the risk of fire spread.           
Neither accident was reported to the Marine Accident Investigation Branch (MAIB) nor to the management company's Designated Person Ashore (DPA).
Recommendations have been made to A.P. Møller Maersk which include a review of internal and external communication procedures, control of contractors, hot work arrangements and accident reporting procedures.  The company has also been recommended to issue instructions on securing of mooring equipment for sea and preserving voyage data recorder information for accident investigation purposes.
The repair contractor has been recommended to ensure that no flammable material is left near gas bottles, its workers are equipped with Very High Frequency (VHF) radios, a safety watchman is always available, that gas connection leak tests are carried out and, where feasible, "in use" bottles are separated from those in the  storage area.

On 11th November 2008 the QE2 ran aground at 05.02 hours LT whilst attempting to navigate the particularly tight turn into the Thorn Channel, Southampton Water, during a routine entry to her home port of Southampton.   
Whilst initiating the turn the ship's head fell off the wind very quickly, and driven on by her forward momentum, continued to swing with an increasing rate of turn.  
The pilot and bridge team monitored the turn, but remedial action was ineffective in bringing the ship back into position, compounded by a loss of manoeuvrability due to reducing underkeel clearance and "stalling" from the speed reduction caused by the hard over manoeuvre and then abeam wind.   When it became apparent that the ship would not be able to line up with their navigable channel, the ship's master made the prudent decision to run her aground on a windward, gently shelving beach rather than risk forcing her round out with the extreme edge of the channel, or attempting a crash stop, whereupon she would have soon drifted onto a steeper, harder lee shore.
The ship was refloated soon afterwards in the rising tide.  There were no injuries, damage to ship, nor pollution as a result of the grounding.

InitialEvent: Hull failure / failure of watertight doors / ports, etc.
SummaryOfEvents:
Maersk Newport sailed from Le Havre for Algeciras just after midnight on 10 November 2008 in force 4 to 5 winds.  Overnight the weather deteriorated and the ship's speed was reduced.  By 12.00 hours LT the wind had further increased to force 8 to 9  with rough seas.  At 12.50 the bow thruster room bilge alarm sounded and a number of holes were found in the port side of the bow thruster room shell plating through which water was pouring.  The port anchor chain lashing was found to have released and the anchor had fallen, against the windlass brake tension, into the water.  As the ship had plunged the anchor had impacted against the hull causing the damage.  It was later found that five adjacent compartments had also flooded.
Despite the forecasted poor weather conditions no specific heavy weather checks had been carried out.  By the time they were considered necessary it was too dangerous for personnel to go on to the deck and so the anchor security was not verified.  The anchor chain lashing arrangement failed because neither it, nor the windlass brake, was sufficiently tightened and the hawse pipe covers were not fitted.  
The vessel continued her passage and arrived at Algeciras on 13 November 2008 for cargo operations and repair.

Fire detection was not working, and the crew was unfamiliar with proper fire fighting. Release station of CO2 bottles could not then be reached due to expanding fire. InitialEvent: Accident to seafarer, engineer scalded by steam and hot water
SummaryOfEvents:
A dirty water drain from the fuel oil separators was obstructed and needed cleaning. The drain, a 2½’’ pipe, was supposed for draining water and oil from four fuel oil separators into a common dirty water tank ventilated to the atmosphere. The drain pipe was heated by steam tracing and furnished with at blind flange for opening and cleaning of the pipe as a part of the ship’s design.

The 4th engineer dismantled a blind flange and poked with a wire into the pipe and the sludge inside burst out and hit the engineer all over. It was between 1300 and 1330.

The engineer was scalded in his face, on his neck, arms, and hands, thighs, fore-legs, ankles and feet. 

The 4th engineer was transferred to the ship’s hospital where he was put in the bath tub and cooling with cold water was continued. The engineer received first aid and treatment for his burns and to prevent chock. Later on the same day he was transferred by a helicopter to a hospital.

Four crewmen were asleep on boar and were not aware that there was a problem until the flooding caused the ship to become unstable and roll violently to port, throwing three of the crew from their bunks. The roll was stopped when the mast and dredging machine came into contact with the adjacent quay. It is unlikely that the mooring line would have restrained Abigail H if it had rolled away from the quay, and the crew were extremely fortunate to escape without injury.

1.1	The cruise vessel BLACK WATCH was berthed at Gexto Pier In Bilbao on 29th October 2008, when in the early afternoon winds began to increase and become gusting.  The vessel’s master took action to improve the mooring pattern forward  - the end of the vessel taking the  greatest impact of the North Westerly wind – but at approximately 14:15 ship’s time (UTC + 1) an exceptionally large gust peaking to 50 knots, accompanied by a shift of wind direction to the North, caused an increase of pitching and rolling movements of the vessel and parting of moorings forward.  All of the forward moorings parted with the exception of two lines, one of them a breast line on a drum, and  the other a spring line on bitts that was not contributing to lateral restraint. Although the remaining lines did not part they were unable to hold the vessel alongside. 
1.2	As the vessel’s bow swung away from the berth the gangway fell from the quayside and a passenger and AB on the gangway were projected into the seas below.  A second passenger who was close to the end of the gangway also fell into the sea.
1.3	Two other passengers on shore were struck by parting rope tails but sustained only minor injuries.  There was potential for very serious injury that was fortunately avoided. 
1.4	With three persons in the water the vessel’s staff responded by throwing life rings to the casualties in the water and preparing to launch the Man-overboard (rescue) Boat.  The life rings served to keep casualties afloat until assistance arrived in the form of a harbour boat, which was fast enough to suspend the launching of the vessel’s own boat.  Further life rings were thrown by shore staff from the pier.  One of the casualties – an elderly female – was unconscious.  She was kept afloat by the AB.
1.5	The passengers were rescued first and attended to by paramedics ashore before being taken to hospital.  The AB was rescued subsequently and after medical checks returned to work on board the vessel.  The passengers struck by lines were attended to by ship’s medical staff.  All have since made a full recovery.
1.6	After the casualties were removed from the water the vessel was manoeuvred alongside with the assistance of tugs, and by using her own thrusters forward.  
1.7	The vessel sailed from Bilbao at 17:54 on 29th October for Honfleur in France after which her next port of call was Dover in the UK, where this preliminary enquiry was carried out on 1st November 2008.

InitialEvent: Hull failure / failure of watertight doors / ports, etc.
SummaryOfEvents:
On 23rd October 2008 the ro-ro cargo ferry STENA VOYAGER was on its usual Irish Sea crossing from the UK mainland to Northern Ireland.  The weather forecast on sailing was for strong winds (F6-7) with wave heights predicted to be about 3.5 metres.  The off-going master advised the on-coming master that the conditions were fairly rough, but not unusual, and he had experienced 3.5 metre waves during his last crossing.

On sailing the weather conditions were as forecasted but about half way through the crossing the conditions deteriorated.  The wind was 45 knots (F9) from the south-west, the sea had become rough with up to 5 metre waves, and there was a heavy southerly swell running.  The master reduced speed to 10 knots but soon after, at approximately 14.40 hours LT, a series of large wave crashed onto the hulls which caused obvious damage, but the vessel made its way safely into port.  

Investigations found that the composite hull panels and the reinforcing GRP overlay panels had twisted, causing cracking and failure of the panels and of the internal stainless steel wire bonding and tensioning arrangements.  The damaged area was not part of the hull structure but was the cosmetic fairing of the forward part of the hulls.

The local MCA Marine Office surveyed the damage and agreed a temporary repair plan until the next docking in Jan 09.  A new operating limit of use in maximum 3.5 metre seas was also imposed until full repairs were undertaken.

There were no personal injuries to either the 380 passengers or 35 crew.

On 10th October 2008 the Liberian-flagged bulk carrier FEDRA had suffered main engine failure and was at anchorage off Gibraltar Island.  Bad weather and heavy seas caused the vessel to crash repeatedly into rocky cliffs, resulting in the spillage of 150 tons of fuel oil and the the vessel's total destruction. A rescue helicopter and four tugs lifted the 31 crew members to safety.
Consequences1: Pollution,Ship rendered unfit to proceed,Total loss of the ship

SOLASStatus: KAMAL XXIX: Unknown/unspecified, ORIENTAL MARGUERITE: SOLAS
SummaryOfEvents:
On 6th October 2008 the Panamanian tanker ORIENTAL MARGUERITE arrived at Kandla and dropped anchor at outer anchorage at 15.30 hours LT.
At 02.50 hours on 8th October 2008 she was shifting to Pilot boarding station under Kandla tower instruction.
The Kandla pilot requested that the vessel headed toward buoys no. 2 and 3, and confirmed that Pilot would transfer from outbound vessel Karagol when she passed from port to port.
Master and OOW had observed one ship was outbound in the channel approx 6 miles away but Kandla tower control and Pilot were not informed regarding Dredger movement in the channel. However it was noted that dredger “Kamal no. 29” was located on starboard bow side of vessel with bearing of 70 deg. and speed approx 70 knots.
The The ORIENTAL MARGUERITE overreached the pilot boarding location and Master ordered engine to be stopped in order to make pick up. At the time of the incident the Pilot boat was on the vessel's starboard side, but the Master was worried about the approach of dredger "Kamal No.29" which was then less than 1 mile away. Master ordered wheel hard to port with minimum ahead, and then full astern engine in order to avoid a collision, but it could not be avoided. After the incident the ship's condition was checked and it was discovered that FPT inflow water was coming in through damaged part of bulbous bow, which was damaged and heavily dented as a result of the collision. 
Master immediately reported incident to company and pilot informed the Port authority, which requested that the vessel be moved to inner anchorage. Vessel was berthed at VIKAS No. 5 berth at 11.35 hours LT on 8th October 2008, and commenced discharge cargo operations without any trouble.

On October 7th, 2008, about 18:15 hrs, 13 miles west of Umag, during loading of the catch on the fishing ship "Mirna Dva", there was a rupture of pulley which caused death of one crew member and one injured crew member.

Location: In the vicinity of Nakanose lighthouse, Hiroshima Prefecture, Japan
SummaryOfEvents: On 7th October 2008 the 3628gt Panamanian registered container ship NORFOLD was en route from Takamatsu to Hiroshima, carrying 90 marine freight containers, when she ran aground in the vicinity of Nakanose lighthouse, Hiroshima Prefecture, Japan at about 04.17 hours LT.  The ship leaked a small amount of fuel, which was dispersed subsequently. After refloating under her own power on high tide, and undergoing a temporary repair, she arrived at Hiroshima port. There was no damage to the lighthouse and no injury to the crew.

The Virginiaborg transited the Kiel-Canal in ballast sailing to the Great Lakes in the United State via Oxelösund in Sweden. 
The ship hit a concrete wall outside the lock of Brunsbüttel. After an inspection by the master, the pilot and lock personnel, the damage revealed was only an indentation outside the no 6 starboard fuel oil tank.
The ship managing companies was informed but not the recognized organizations.
On 3 October 2008, information has been given to the Virginiaborg to bunker heavy fuel oil (HFO) and marine gas oil (MGO) off Skagen, Denmark. On the 6 October 2008, the ship anchored for bunkering of HFO/MGO near the tanker Dana.
When the bunkering of HFO was approximately 80% completed, an oil film had been observed on the water at 18:35. The bunkering was stopped, the HFO was leaking from a crack in the Virginiaborg starboard side aft. 
In spite of a deployment of an oil boom in attempt to contain the spillage, a total of 400-500 litres leaked
The rest of the HFO was transferred to Virginiaborg other HFO tanks. The pollution control vessel Gunnar Thorson estimated that no additional action was deemed necessary than what was already done by Dana. A search by helicopter conducted in the 7 October confirmed the absence of further pollution in the area.

At 00:30 hours LT on 5 October 2008, the registered Container Vessel MAERSK BATAM, call sign 9VHF2, GT 35.835, 3.100 TEU, 223 m (LOA), flag Singapore, built May 2008, without pilot on board and 23 crew and 4 passengers, engine type 8K89MC-C, power output (KW) 28.880, collided with the wall of the wharf of Port of Itajaí. This was as a result of the stern mooring ropes having been broken by the heavy rainfall and strong currents of the river Itajaí Açú.  At the moment of the accident the  ship  was moored by starboard in cradle nº 03 of the wharf at the Port of Itajaí.
As a result of the collision, MAERSK BATAM sustained scratches and two holes to her starboard. There was no pollution by oil in the sea and no personal injuries were observed. The ship remained fit to proceed.

Le 30 Septembre 2008, le navire de pêche Elise appareille du port du Havre, vers 06:00 heures, pour se rendre dans le secteur du Cap de la Hève.

A ce moment le ciel est nuageux, le vent est du secteur Ouest 27 nœuds, la mer agitée, le patron estime que les conditions météorologiques lui permettent de prendre la mer.

Vers 09:00 heures, après avoir viré les 15 quinze premiers casiers d’une filière, le patron voit arriver sur bâbord  une très grosse déferlante. Il fait couper la filière et se met   bout à la lame en poussant son moteur au maximum.

Malgré cette manœuvre, la déferlante couvre le navire. Trois à quatre seconde après, l’Elise se couche rapidement sur tribord, puis se retourne, quille en l’air, à environ 300 mètres du rivage.

Le matelot se retrouve à l’eau et le patron est coincé à l’intérieur de la timonerie. Vu la rapidité de l’événement,  le patron ne peut donner l’alerte par les moyens dont il dispose à bord. Il réussit cependant à s’extirper  de la timonerie et à s’accrocher aux sabords du navire. Il voit son matelot en train de regagner la côte à la nage.

Le navire auquel le patron est accroché, poussé par le vent, dérive vers la côte. Arrivé non loin du rivage, la timonerie touche les hauts fonds et le patron se met à l’eau pour regagner la grève, ce qu’il parvient à faire avec grande difficulté. Après avoir repris son souffle, il se dirige vers un établissement aquacole distant de 800 mètres, qu’il atteint vers 10:00 et où l’alerte peut être donnée.

Si le patron à pu regagné la côte par ses propres moyens et donner l’alerte, le matelot, quant à lui, a disparu.

D’importants moyens de recherche et de sauvetage aériens, maritimes et terrestres sont dépêchés sur la zone du  naufrage par le Centre Régional Opérationnel de Surveillance et de Sauvetage de Jobourg (CROSS) afin de retrouver le marin. Le patron en état d’hypothermie, est hospitalisé.

Le corps du matelot est découvert le 05 Octobre 2008, entre Cauville et Octeville-Sur-Mer.

Location: Black sea,at about 14 nautical miles to the East from Emine Cape.
InitialEvent: Hull failure / failure of watertight doors / ports, etc.
SummaryOfEvents:
On 27.09.2008, at 04:05 hours LT, an EPIRB distress signal was received at Varna MRCC from Moscow MRCC from a point with probable coordinates at about 14 nautical miles to the East from Emine Cape. 
After execution of initial actions and respective operational procedures for identification of distress signal the hypothesis for casualty of m/v „Tolstoy” in a point with coordinates: φ = 42°44’ N, λ = 028°12'E was accepted as reliable.
Search and rescue operations were conducted from 10.15 hours LT on 27.09.2008  to 17.30 hours LT on 01.10.2008. Ships and a navy helicopter, Border Police and MAEA all participated in the operation. The hydro-meteorological conditions of sea region were: wind from NNE, force of wind 8 (17.2÷20.7 m/s), heavy sea 5 (about 4 m height of waves). The vessel sank, two crew members were rescued by "Mirage", a yacht navigating under the Belgian flag. The other 8 crew members were declared missing as a result of the foundering of m/v „Tolstoy”.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
AOn 26th September 2008 the hopper dredger SAND HERON  was engaged in anchoring trials while making slow passage from Hull to Teesport.  At the time of the accident one of two contractors were burning off damaged sections of the hoppers using the ship's oxy-acetylene burning equipment.  The four oxygen and acetylene cylinders were stowed in separate cabinets on the upper deck.  The equipment was supposedly fitted with non-return valves at the inlet to the blowpipe and flame arresters at the discharge from the regulating valves in accordance with normal practice.

At about 13.45 hours LT the nozzle of the blowpipe became partially blocked by burnt metal particles.  Instead of shutting off the gas and using the correct cleaning tool, the burner opted to "blow through" the system using the oxygen supply.  Soon after, a loud "pop" was heard and black smoke was seen to come from the acetylene gas cupboard.  The fire was reported to the bridge and three fire hoses were rigged distant from the cabinet.  About 10 minutes later the smoke appeared to have reduced.  At 14.01 hours LT the chief engineer assessed that the fire had come from an acetylene hose and considered it safe to shut off the bottle valve.  However, as he cautiously opened the cabinet doors, flames were still seen in the cabinet.  The chief engineer retreated and the fire hoses were directed onto the burning acetylene hose.  At 14.05 hours LT the local coastguard were alerted from transmissions to VTS of the incident.  It was presumed that, because there was not a bottle explosion, the flame arrestor had worked and that the flame was external to the bottle.  It was on this basis that the chief engineer approached the bottle once again, and under cover of the fire hoses he managed to close the acetylene bottle valve and extinguish the fire.  
The coastguard was immediately advised and they put the master in contact with the local Fire and Rescue Service Liaison Officer who was content that no further action was needed.  The vessel then made its way towards its next port.  

Subsequent advice from the company's Safety Officer instructed the vessel to go to anchor as soon as possible and he also advised that the incorrect safety information had been given.  The master was informed that acetylene bottles may self heat if they have been subjected to flame impingement and that the risk remained for 24 hours.  The vessel went to anchor and water was sprayed over the acetylene bottles for a further 24 hours.

Investigation found that the MRCC watch manager contacted the local Fire and Rescue Service instead of contacting the Maritime Incident Response Group (MIRG) Liaison Officer who would have provided the correct advice via the local Fire and Rescue Service in that the bottles should be cooled and an exclusion area established.  It further transpired that the person providing the advice was not an operational fire fighting officer.

It was also possible that the heated bottle could have exhibited vibration set up by the ship's movement which could have led to an explosion and in this case ship evacuation would have been recommended.  It is worth noting that if the incident had happened ashore, a 200 metre exclusion zone would have been established lasting for 24 hours.

Further investigation by the ship safety officer identified that although the non-return valves and hoses had been subjected to annual inspection by a competent person there was little guidance on how to test the flame arrestors.

The "popping!" sound heard just before the fire is typical of "backfire" when the flame ignites the gasses inside the blowpipe when the torch is held too close to the work piece.  In this case it is likely that the flame travelled past the non-return valve and was stopped at the arrester fitted just before the regulator valves.  It is likely that the hose that failed had been damaged in some way causing it to fail and the flame to be established.

An independent report on the burning equipment was undertaken by BOC.  Their report identified that the nozzle had become over heated as a result of a partial blockage.  This resulted in the acetylene mixing with the oxygen supply in the torch mixing chamber when it was re-opened.  Because the non-return valves were not fitted the flame travelled up to the flame arrester where it was prevented from travelling into the acetylene bottle.  The flame front pressure can typically reach 75 bar and as the hose is pressure tested to 65 bar it is capable of bursting the hose, as in this case, releasing the gas to feed the fire. 

Fire damage was superficial and was limited to the burning equipment hoses and cosmetic damage to the acetylene bottle storage cabinet.

The bulk carrier M.V. “TRUST THALASAA” sailed from her last port of call Yeosu, South Korea on 20 September 2008 to port Totoralillo, Chile. This passage was of a total distance 9900 nm with her E.T.A. 24 October 08 at destination. The vessel was in ballast condition.
On 25 September, 08 the day of the incident, while the vessel was progressing on her passage at sea, the crew were assigned a job of cargo hold cleaning.
The crew working at no.5 hatch track used an unconventional and unapproved lifting rig comprising of a portable boom with wooden blocks and nylon ropes to pick up cargo residues from hold by use of mooring winch. At a time three pails were picked up in every lift. 
At around 1540 hrs the davit boom broke and hit two crew members who were attending to it on deck. The upper part of the boom gave way at the welding seam causing serious injuries to attending crew. 
The bridge was informed and the crew was mustered at the site of accident for assistance. The casualties were given first aid and transferred to the ship’s hospital.
Japan and Guam coast guard were communicated for medical assistance and vessel was diverted towards Hachijo Island in Japan as recommended by R.C.C, Japan.
Vessel being closer to Guam the coast guard and vessel’s owner advised her to head towards Guam instead of Japan.  The vessel maintained communication channel with shore stations for reporting the condition of casualties at frequent intervals and obtaining medical advice. 
Late night on 26 September, the U.S. Coast guard search and rescue controllers in Guam boarded the vessel with doctors and medical equipments for urgent medical assistance.
Early morning on 28 September in position about 30nm north east of Saipan, both the casualties were air lifted by naval helicopter to naval hospital. They were later reported of being shifted to Guam Memorial Hospital.
The vessel received the information through Guam agent on 28 September who was told by hospital authorities that one of the crew had expired en-route to Guam before reaching the medical facility while the second crew member was under medical treatment but out of danger.

The bulk carrier M.V. “Occam’s Razor” sailed from her last port of call Yeosu, South Korea on 20 September 2008 to port Totoralillo, Chile. This passage was a total distance 9900 nm with her E.T.A. 24th October 2008. The vessel was in ballast condition.
On 25th September 2008, while the vessel was at sea, the crew were assigned a job of cargo hold cleaning.
The crew working at no.5 hatch track used an unconventional and unapproved lifting rig comprising of a portable boom with wooden blocks and nylon ropes to pick up cargo residues from the hold by use of a mooring winch. The pails were picked up three at a time in each lift.

Japan and Guam coast guard were communicated for medical assistance and vessel was diverted towards Hachijo Island in Japan as recommended by R.C.C, Japan.

Location: 25 nm south of Hong Kong, China
SummaryOfEvents:
At about 02:45 hours in the morning on 24 September 2008, a very serious marine casualty occurred on board the 8749 TEU ship Chicago Express sailing under German flag, in which a Philippine crew member was fatally injured, the German Master of the ship suffered serious injuries, and four more German seaman suffered minor injuries.

At about 17:30 hours on the previous day, the ship put to sea from Hong Kong and sailed for Ningbo following  instruction to shipping form the local port authority because of the approaching Typhoon "Hagupit". At about 19:45 hours, immediately after reaching the open sea, the Chicago Express encountered heavy winds and swell from a south-easterly direction, this exposed the ship to rolling motions of up to approximately 32 degrees. The ship's command therefore decided to deviate from the intended general north-easterly course towards Ningbo and weather the storm, which at the time of the accident had reached a wind force of 10 with gusts of up to 12 Bft, by steering variable courses against the direction of the wind and swell. This led to the roll angle being reduced to values of about 20 degrees. 
At about 02:45 hours, the ship, which at the time was  under the control of the Master and steered by  the Helmsman manually, was suddenly hit by a particularly violent wave coming from starboard  just as she rolled to starboard. Following that, the Chicago Express keeled over several times, at which the inclinometer registered an (uncorrected) maximum roll angle of 44 degrees for an estimated period of 10 seconds. Due to the enormous accelerative forces on the bridge, the Master, the Helmsman and the Lookout (AB) also present lost their footing and were thrown across the bridge. The officer on watch, who was the only person on the bridge able to hold on to the chart table, hurried to the helm and stabilised the quickly and after a short period of orientation, he and the officer on watch found both the Master and the AB lying unconscious on the floor with bleeding wounds. While the Master regained partial consciousness shortly after, in spite of immediately initiated first aid measures carried out with the assistance of other summoned crew members and guided by medical consultations via radio (Medico Cuxhaven), they were unable to save the unconscious AB. At 04:17 hours, resuscitative measures were discontinued.

At the same time as the rescue operations on board, the ship's command established contact with MRCC Bremen and MRCC Hong Kong and organised the evacuation of the severely injured Master. At about 07:53 hours, after the weather had calmed, a rescue helicopter from Hong Kong, China  by MRCC Hong Kong, China reached the ship, took the Master on board and transported him to a hospital in Hong Kong. The Chicago Express subsequently also returned to Hong Kong, China to hand over the body of the AB and facilitate the investigation of the accident by the coastal state. The Chicago Express left the port of Hong Kong, China for the final time on 26 September 2008 at 14:00 hours.

During the ensuing weeks, the Master, who was in acute danger of losing his life for an extended period because of the severity of his internal injuries, initially received medical care in Hong Kong, China and was flown to Germany after his fitness to travel was restored.

On 24th September 2008 the general cargo ship ZEUS was en route from Danang, Vietnam bound for Masan , Korea, carrying a cargo of silica. The vessel was attempting to anchor around an island to avoid a typhoon when she was hit by the typhoon and split in two. ZEUS capsized with the loss of  all 17 crew members.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

InitialEvent: Accident to person during heavy weather
SummaryOfEvents: On 23rd September 2008 the container ship MAERSK KITHIRA was at sea when the bilge alarms sounded. The Chief officer and chief engineer went forward during rough weather to investigate the alarms, which had been set off by the leaking of water through a rope hatch into the bosun's store. Both men went to the forecastle to secure the hatch, but while doing so a large wave washed over the forecastle, knocking both men over. The Chief officer raised the alarm and an emergency team was sent to the forecastle to recover the men. Once in the sick bay, first aid was applied and radio medical advice sought concerning the injuries to the chief engineer. However, despite the best efforts of those on board, the chief engineer died shortly before the ship arrived at the next port
Consequences1: Loss of life,Serious injuries,Ship remains fit to proceed

Location: Waters off the east coast of Sado-ga-Shima Island
SummaryOfEvents:
The recreational fishing vessel Koyo Maru No. 7 left the East Section of Niigata Port, Niigata City, Niigata Prefecture, on September 20, 2008, carrying ten persons on board, namely, her skipper, owner, and eight passengers. At about 0500 hours on the 21st of the same month, on her return trip to Niigata, after
fishing in fishing grounds north of Sado-ga-Shima Island, Niigata Prefecture, seawater found its way into the vessel through her propeller inspection port in the aft section, and the recreational fishing vessel sank halfway between Sado-ga-Shima Island and Niigata Port, at about 0645 hours. The skipper and two passengers drowned and two other passengers were hospitalized for pneumonia or otherwise.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Serious injuries,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
The Polaris was on its way from Bremerhaven to Kotka, Finland while the Crownbreeze was on its way from Rostock to Cork, Ireland. Both vessels collided with their forecastle areas at 04:55 hours.
Following the collision, the Polaris ran into the north bank, where it became stranded with the bow at Canal kilometres 55.5. A short time later she was able to get clear herself without assistance. The Crownbreeze was pushed toward the north bank but was able to escape from the critical situation.
On board the Polaris, numerous damages of the forecastle area, to the bulwark on the port side and to the superstructure at the stern were identified. As a result of contact with the bank, the steering gear no longer worked correctly. As the ship continued on its voyage, it had become apparent that the rudder actually laid midships when the rudder position indicator indicated between 15° and 25°.
On board the Crownbreeze, heavy damage was also determined in the bow area. At the stern, there was damage on the bridge roof and scraped paint in the stern area on port side.

Early in the morning on the 18th of September 2008, the fishing vessel TARA collided with the general cargo ship REBECCA ROUSING. It was dark and the weather was calm with good visibility.
Subsequently both vessels were fit to proceed to berth. No persons were injured.

InitialEvent: Danger due to suction and waves
SummaryOfEvents:
The container ship WMS Groningen, sailing under the Cypriot flag, was on voyage from Fredericia (Denmark) to Hamburg on 14 September 2008.
On the Elbe level with the Wittenbergen jetty, suction and waves were produced by the ship at around 15:25 hours during an overtaking manoeuvre, endangering a group of five adults and six children due to excessive swell.

Whilst participating in the annual Sean Whiston Perpetual Cup Race from Wicklow to the Poolbeg Yacht Club in Dublin, the Yacht "Alana" lost a crewmember overboard of Bray Head, Co. Wicklow at approximately 13:30 hours on 14 September 2008. 

A yacht in the vicinity, the Naomh Cronan, assisted in the rescue the crewmember from the water, and attempts were made to resuscitate him.

An eyewitness stated that the crewmember PDF (Personal Flotation Device) was not inflated.

The crewmember was airlifted by Coast Guard Helicopter direct to the Adelaide and Meath Hospital, Tallaght, Dublin where he was pronounced dead.

The cause of death was due to drowning, on a background of severe coronary artery disease.

M/V “DIMITRIOS P” capsized alongside loading berth at Derince port in Turkey, during loading 1130 tons of steel bars and steel construction “H” profiles, due to a sudden and critical cargo shifting during the completion of loading . The Master of the vessel failed to implement properly the aforementioned code for reasons not specified. Failure of the lashing equipment resulted in sudden and unacceptable cargo shifting which consequently listed the vessel beyond her survival stability limits. All crew members (7 in total, including Master) managed to escape from the vessel and save their lives with minor injuries. Three of them were transported to the local hospital for first aid and thereafter came back in order to provide statements to the Authorities who commenced investigation and legal procedures in respect of the incident.

Location: off St. Nazaire, Bay of Biscay
InitialEvent: Hull failure / failure of watertight doors / ports, etc.
SummaryOfEvents: Water ingress was observed in the Trainee Mess.  The crew attempted to pump the flood water out without success.  The ship was abandoned by liferaft at approximately 01.50 hrs.  No loss of life occurred and there were no injuries reported.

The general cargo ship NOREN departed Skelleftehamn, Sweden on 5th September 2008 with destination Hull, UK, carrying a load of sawn timber. On the 7th September, just before midnight, the Officer on Watch noticed that the gyrocompass had broken down, so he changed over to hand steering and called the Master. At around 02.00 in the morning of 8th September the Captain said that he took some vodka to be able to sleep.
The Captain started his ordinary watch the same morning at 08.00. The relieved OOW and the helmsman could smell alcohol on the Captains breath. After passing the lighthouse Pinhättan, in the Sound, he altered course too early and passed on the wrong side of the buoy Valgrundet, and grounded.

InitialEvent: Fell between ship and Barge while climbing Jacob Ladder
SummaryOfEvents:
The ship loaded a cargo of 20,136 MT of Gas oil from berth “B” Reliance Terminal on 07 Sept 2008, and anchored at the customary anchorage at 1411 hrs on the same day, for receiving bunkers and stores.

At 1434 hrs on the same day, bunker barge “Hope Island” was made fast on the port side and at 1440 hrs the stores boat came alongside on the starboard side. Chief Officer went to attend to the stores boat and asked Bosun to rig ladder as per Chief Engineer’s instructions. Chief Engineer asked for a pilot ladder to be rigged and at 1440 hrs Bosun rigged a Jacob ladder for transfer of personnel between ship & bunker barge. At 1525 hrs, 4th Engineer (wearing his life jacket) used the ladder to transfer to the bunker barge for gauging the tanks of the bunker barge and one of the barge personnel boarded the Gulf Nomad.

At 1603 hrs 4th Engineer started climbing back to the Gulf Nomad on the Jacob ladder. At 1605 hrs, whilst Chief Engineer was in discussion with the barge personnel and bunker hose connection was in progress by the Fitter and Motorman, a splash was heard of something falling in the water on the port side. On checking over side, C/E saw that 4th Engineer had fallen in to the water between the ship and the barge. C/E called for help and bridge was informed & MOB alarm raised. The alerted barge crew immediately responded to rescue 4/Eng and get him onboard the barge - at 1610 hrs 4/Eng was pulled onboard the bunker barge, still wearing his life jacket.

At 1620 hrs Ch Officer and Electrical Officer transferred to the bunker barge to render assistance to 4/Eng and to evaluate his condition. First aid was rendered and radio Medical Advice obtained by phone. It was observed that 4/Eng right arm was swollen and there were bruises on the stomach. The 4/Eng was semi conscious and was trying to say something, but was in a deep state of shock. 

At 1645 hrs Mr. Periris was transferred to the stores boat and the boat was away from the ship at 1650 hrs. Agents had been informed and a doctor was made stand by at the boat jetty along with an ambulance.

InitialEvent: crew fell overboard while rigging pilot ladder
SummaryOfEvents:
At about 1849 (Local Time) on 4 September 2008, when the Hong Kong, China registered car carrier HUA XING was leaving Ulsan, a Seaman I fell overboard from the bottom platform of the accommodation ladder while he was engaged in recovering the pilot ladder on the starboard side.
The Master reported the accident to the Vessel Traffic Services (VTS) of Ulsan at 1858 and VTS initiated a search and rescue (SAR) operation for the Seaman I. Despite the SAR operation was jointly conducted by a pilot boat, two tugboats and four Coast Guard boats, the missing Seaman I could not be found. The SAR operation were stopped at 1100 on the next day, i.e. on 5 September 2008, when the body of the missing Seaman I was found by a fishing boat.

Location: near the Greek island Kos, in the Aegean Sea
SummaryOfEvents:
On September 4th 2008, M/V “DERYA 2” grounded near the Greek island Kos, in the Aegean Sea, inside Greek territorial waters. After ten (10) hours, she was able to refloat by own means and proceeded towards her next destination (Kerch, Ukraine) despite the recommendations of the Greek Authorities and denying every control. 
During interview of ship’s Captain on October 1st 2008 in Istanbul, Turkey, he claimed that once he was able to sail again without any external assistance, he considered that it was unnecessary to further delay therefore he proceeded to his next destination ignoring the Greek authorities and without any objective assessment of the condition of vessel’s underwater parts. After examination of all the available details and with absolutely subjective evaluation thereof, it seems that the Captain failed to comply with the Hellenic Authorities instructions on purpose, while no extenuating circumstances were found.

Location: West coast of Vancouver Island, British Columbia
SummaryOfEvents: On the earlier morning of 04 September 2008, the small fishing ship Love and Anarchy capsized and sank while anchored on Swift sure Bank, 20 nautical miles southwest of Cape Beale, British Columbia. The owner and a crew member aboard were rescued by another fishing vessel.
Consequences1: Serious injuries,Total loss of the ship

SOLASStatus: THE VENETIAN: Unknown/unspecified, YUE TAI SHAN 33040: Unknown/unspecified
Location: Qing Zhou HSC Traffic Separation Scheme
SummaryOfEvents:
On 2 September 2008, the Hong Kong, China registered passenger high speed craft THE VENETIAN was en route from Hong Kong, China to Macau. At 1142, she collided with a Chinese fishing vessel YUE TAI SHAN 33040 at the approximate position 22-11.58'N  113-41.0'E near to the No.2 buoy within the Qing Zhou HSC Traffic Separation Scheme in Chinese waters.
As a result of the collision, THE VENETIAN sustained minor structural damage on forward part of the hulls while YUE TAI SHAN 33040 was broken up and sank. The Master and his wife onboard YUE TAI SHAN 33040 fell into water. The wife was rescued by nearby fishing vessels and sent to hospital in Macau. But the Master of the fishing vessel was missing and his death body was found later.

The bulk carrier VINASHIN IRON was navigating in the Mongla / Zulfiquar channel to pick-up Pilot at Hiron point P/Stn on 02 September 2008. At 08.23 hours LT, as she was approaching buoy no.  B-12 on port bow, she altered her course to 0.45 degrees. The vessel then altered her course further to 0.55 degress when buoy no. B-14 came into view on the port bow, as Port control had instructed her to pass buoy no. B-13 closely at 0.2 miles(2 cables).  These maneouvres resulted in her speed decreasing to zero and and the echo sounder depth  showing zero. (Grounding posn: 21-39.00N, 089-28.39E).
The vessel grounded due to presence of an uncharted shoal whose position was not marked on the vessel's latest/new BA chart 732 and not advised by port. 

    VINASHIN IRON informed port control of the incident and was requested to head the vessel to the southeast with full ahead engines and try to clear by hard port/starboard rudder. Thereafter, contacted Head office and informed vessel manager. All tanks sounded continuously and no ingress of water was noticed.

   Upon investigation by port authorities and the harbour master, who boarded  the vesssel on 5th September 2008, the cause of the grounding was not clear as the charted depth was deeper and no shoal was indicated.

Location: off the approaches to the Port of Tanjung Pelapas, Johor, West Malaysia
SummaryOfEvents:
At 0930 hours on 23 August 2008, the Liberian registered container vessel MAERSK MIAMI (MM) collided with the anchored Panamanian chemical tanker MT NORD STRAIT (NS) at the inshore traffic zone off the approaches to the Port of Tanjung Pelapas, Johor, West Malaysia. MM sustained damage to its port side hull above water level. A cut of about 1 metre long, penetrated her shell plating and holed just below her deck line, near its midship section. 

The collision occurred when MM was maneuvering to pick up pilot for berthing at Tanjung Pelapas Maersk’s container berth. The incident position being Latitude 01° 14.00’ Longitude 103° 30.5’E, outside Tanjung Pelapas Port limit, about 1.3 nautical miles from the pilot station.  At the time of the collision, the weather was fine with good visibility, low swell and sea.

There was no injury or fatality on the NS. Neither was there report of injury or fatality from the MM.

NS sustained minor damage to its forecastle deck (see Annex A47 – NK Class damage report certification). Its forward bulwark, collapsed inwards. It bulbous bow also sustained indentation, but not holed. Her seaworthiness was not affected and temporary repairs were carried out in Singapore. After the temporary repair, NS proceeded to Taiwan, China and discharged her cargoes of jet fuel before returning to Singapore for dry docking and permanent repairs. 

There was no pollution resulting from the collision.  

The investigation highlighted the main contributory factor to this incident as poor application of BRM on the MM resulting in failure to keep clear of other vessel.

The investigation identifies the following safety issues:

•	Based on VTIS information, the execution of bridge resource management on board the MM was inadequate because single person errors, such as the loss of situational awareness and decision making went unchecked.

•	Inadequate bridge procedures or inadequate passage plan, with respect to identifying the set and drift and monitoring and managing traffic around itself in critical and confined water maneuvers.

•	The failure to respond to radio communication thus not making all available measures to reduce the risk of collision in good time.

SOLASStatus: SURFING JAD: SOLAS, YOSSA BHUM: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents:
Bulk Carrier MV Surfing Jad arrived at Pipavav, Gujarat, India from Umm al-Quwain, U.A.E. on 13 August, 2008 and waited berthing at roads. 
On the day of the incident, 22 August 2008, whilst she was still riding to her starboard anchor at 0250 hrs the duty officer spotted an approaching vessel at 1.5 nm, 2 points aft starboard beam. The vessel was identified on AIS as MV Yossa Bhum, on heading 171° (T) at speed of 10 knots. The track of MV Yossa Bhum was also traced on radar screen of MV Surfing Jad. 
Duty officer made efforts to draw attention of MV Yossa Bhum by calling her on VHF and flashing light by Aldis lamp. However, his call was not acknowledged and MV Yossa Bhum continued to approach towards the vessel. Duty officer raised general alarm and informed master about emergency situation. 
After about 25 minutes of tracking, MV Yossa Bhum collided, making contact of her port side bridge wing to starboard side forecastle deck of MV Surfing Jad.  She sustained several damages on the forecastle deck and also lost her starboard anchor with 4 shackles length of anchor chain.
After collision, MV Yossa Bhum continued at same speed but altered her course towards starboard. Attempts were made by MV Surfing Jad to exchange ship’s particulars and communicate to colliding vessel, if she needed any assistance. The particulars of MV Yossa Bhum identified her as having Singapore flag and IMO No. 9072525
Crew mustered for emergency stations and prepared main engine for maneuvering. All tanks and hold bilges were checked for water ingress, however, no under water damage or leak was identified.
After having lost her anchor, MV Surfing Jad started drifting northward with flood tide. At 05.15 hours she dropped her port anchor with six shackles in water.
In the following two days, the vessel was boarded by Flag state, port state authorities and P & I club surveyors to assess the damages and investigate the incident.

While working to secure the crane, the ship’s boatswain was crushed between the end stop for the crane’s trolley and the railings up on the walkway as the crane’s outriggers were swung in.
None of the other persons who were up on the crane at the time of the accident observed the incident, but the ship’s management was notified as soon as it became clear that the boatswain had been crushed and first aid measures were implemented immediately. The ship’s management also called for medical personnel from ashore, who arrived quickly. Despite the steps taken, it was not possible to save the boatswain’s life.

During a passage from the pilot station into port, the chief and third engineers on board m/v ARK FORWARDER were in the engine control room (ECR) when an electrical earth was detected on the vessel's calorifier sited in the bow thruster compartment. The Electro Technical officer (ETO) was woken at 02.30 hours LT to rectify the fault and arrived in the ECR 10 minutes later. He then made his way to the bow thrusters compartment and, at about 02.50 hours LT, the chief engineer noticed the alarm indicating the earth had stopped. Shortly after, the third engineer left the ECR to conduct routine rounds of the engine room and found the ETO pinned between powered watertight door and its frame. He was unable to open the door to free the ETO because the operating lever was behind the ETO and was obstructed. The third engineer raised the alarm and the ETO was eventually released after the door's hydraulic pressure on the system had been released. The crew's attempts to revive the ETO were not successful and he was pronounced dead by paramedics who met the vessel as she entered Tilbury dock.
The power operated watertight door was set from the bridge to operate in the remote or automatic condition. The exact cause of the accident is unknown but the ETO was attempting to transit the door with tool in his hands which did not give him the use of both hands required to transit the door safely.

Location: At 4.5 miles from Cap De La Heve
SummaryOfEvents:

Il observe une  lourdeur dans le chalut, procède à un lavage du salut en faisant route à petite vitesse  durant environ 15 minutes. Puis il entreprend, après avoir décrocher les panneaux, d’enrouler le chalut sur l’enrouleur.  

Soudainement, alors qu’il vient de virer environ 1.50 mètre de bourrelet, le navire se couche sur bâbord. Il engage son matelot à retirer ciré et bottes et se mettre à l’eau. Il rentre dans la passerelle et essaye sans succès d’atteindre la VHF/ASN, étant aspiré vers le fond avec le navire. Réussissant néanmoins à se dégager, il se retrouve à l’eau avec son matelot et tous deux nagent pour s’écarter du « Marvin » en train de couler. Peu de temps après, le radeau de sauvetage fait surface et  ils y prennent place. Le patron actionne des fumées de détresse  et fait des signaux avec une lampe torche.   

Les naufragés entendent le bruit  d’un moteur et aperçoivent les feux d’un bateau de pêche qui se dirige vers eux. « Le Bon A Rien »  vient à couple  du radeau de sauvetage, récupère les naufragés et les réconforte. Il les débarque ensuite au Havre où ils sont  hospitalisés.

SOLASStatus: DUBLIN EXPRESS: Unknown/unspecified, SD GIRONDE: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents:
Le août 2008 à 03:35 heures locales, le remorqueur portuaire SD Gironde de la Société Nouvelle de remorquage du Havre, battant pavillon français, immatriculé au Have, appareille du quai Johannés Couvert, port du Havre, pour servir le Porte-conteneurs allemand Dublin Express, du large pour le quai de l’Atlantique.
Il est accompagné d’un autre remorqueur, le SD Loire, appartenant à la même société.
A 04:17 heures, alors que le SD Gironde se trouve sur l'avant du Dublin Express, remorque passée et élongée (le SD Gironde se trouvant à l'arrière remorque capelée), l'alarme pression basse air de contrôle moteur principal se déclenche sur chacun des deux moteurs, suivie à 04:18 heures d'un débrayage des deux propulseurs.
Prévenu par le capitaine du SD Gironde de la perte de propulseur du remorqueur, le pilote du Dublin Express demande SD Loire de le ralentir.

Malgré la décision du capitaine de laisser filer la remorque et l'intervention rapide du chef mécanicien pour rétablir la propulsion, le remorqueur ayant perdu la maîtrise de sa manœuvre est heurté par l'étrave du porte-conteneurs une première fois contre son bordé tribord, puis une seconde contre ses superstructures.

Le choc en déformant la coque, provoque la rupture des vannes du réfrigérant eau douce du moteur tribord et l'arrêt des deux moteurs de propulsion par manque de réfrigération. 
 A 05:50 heures, grâce à l'assistance d'un autre remorqueur, le RT Pionner, dépêché sur le lieux par la SNRH, le SD Gironde est pris en remorque et amarré au quai Johannès Couvert.

Quant au Dublin Express, il termine sa manœuvre de présentation  et d'accostage au quai de l'Atlantique avec l'assistance des remorqueurs SD Loire et RT Stéphanie.
Il n'y a pas de blessé ni de pollution. L'abordage qui n'a occasionné que des dégâts matériels principalement au remorqueur, aurait pu avoir des conséquences beaucoup plus importantes. Celui-ci a dû rentrer en cale sèche pour réparation et n'a pu reprendre son service que le 25 Septembre 2008

On 25th July 2008 the roro cargo shp MUIRNEAG had entered the outer harbour of Stornowayand begun to make a 180 degree turn at the narrow entrance to the inner harbour to be able to reverse into the berth. There was a tidal stream of 2 to 3 knots. The master was using a joystick to control two Schilling Vectwin rudders, which were routinely used to produce astern thrust rather than placing the engine astern. During the turn the master realised that the port rudder had responded to astern thrust, but the starboard rudder was still positioned ahead, causing the ship to steer towards a rock shelf. The master ordered the thruster unit into astern but this action did not stop the movement towards the rocks.
