The ship was double banked outboard with M/T “Santa Teresa” of Maltese flag, which was also under repair.

The fire took place with the external space of tank No. 3, between frames 50-61, where workers of the repair contractor “G. SOURLIS EPE – JOIN LTD”, and sub-contractors  “ STYLIANOS AND X. KOSTANTAREAS BROTHERS E.E.” were working at the ships double bottom, who were carrying out steel works using a flame, with a propane oxygen cutting tool.

The fire took place, during the process of finishing the repair works, the reflection and cleaning equipments, to the external side of Cargo tank No.3 and concrete insulation of the tank. The material of the cargo tank insulation is polysterene, which is self-ignited, slow burning and is protected externally by a galvanize 0.5 mm thick sheet.

The reaction of the crew was to try and extinguish the fire, by using the fire and safety abilities, which were on standby, was immediate but without success, so they called the assistance of the national Greek Fire Services Department. They came as fast as they could and they fought with the fire, which was extremely difficult to be extinguished.

The fire was extinguished by the fire services at about 20:50.

The ship’s chief mate, from the Philippines, and one worker from the repair contractor, were immediately found and recovered dead.

Six more workers from the above mentioned contractor were missing, and finally found dead after completion of pumping out works.

The ship’s master remained onboard supervising water pumping out works and ship’s safety in general, as the ship was listed to starboard side, due to flooding.

The water pumping out works were finally completed, as well as locating the missing people.

A representative from the company and a P & I Club representative attended onboard, in order to provide any assistance to the crew etc.


The ship was fully crewed, at the time of casualty and was at the final stage of repairs, and in order the relative Class and Statutory Certificates to be issued by Bureau Veritas.


The work repairs were executed by recognized workshops of different specialties, certified and licensed by port authorities.

Safety engineer was normally daily inspecting the vessel, in order to verify the fire-fighting and safety readiness of the ship, as required by the authorities.

The final death of eight people, the chief officers and seven workers of the repair contractor’s had a result, all newspapers, media and authorities, to give attention to everything and anybody who any connection to the ship, company, and contractors had caused the accident.

A lot of experts and inspectors appointed from different parties in order to investigate the accident.

From the second day, the safety engineer and the marine chemical Engineer were arrested by coast guard, as well as the owner of the workshop, the responsible fireman and the master, in order to proceed to immediate trial which was expiring on 26/07/08.

The court decided the above mentioned people to be imprisoned until the final investigation of the case and new trial to take place on the regular basis. The vessel is still in Perama area.

Case is still pending and will be closed after all parties involved, complete the investigations and appear to court, on the date decided by the judge(this usually takes more than a year in regular basis).

Immediately the general alarm was raised and emergency station called. The welder was found lying unconscious and bleeding form his head and partly burned – no pulse, heart beat was found, his mouth was found jammed by teeth. First (CPR and revival procedures) was administered but there was no response. The welder was then transferred to ship’s hospital and as per company Doctor’s advice all vital were checked and found no any response.

Vessel was immediately diverted to the nearest Port i.e. Lisbon (Portugal) for landing crew which was in a distance of 6 hours from the above position.

On 23rd July 2008 the dry cargo vessel Vinga was underway from Koping in Lake Malaren to Vejle in Denmark carrying a cargo of wheat. Due to the size of the vessel no pilot was required outbound from Koping. When the ship was passing the lighthouse Fifang an alarm from the engine room sounded, indicating lubrication failure to the main engine. The officer on watch called the Master to the bridge and when he saw the type of alarm he immediately ran down to the engine room and stopped the main engine without checking the vessel's position. Shortly afterwards, the vessel ran aground at Vattklubben due to lost steering when the main engine was stopped.

On July 23rd, 2008 at approx. 01.31 hours LT, the Liberian flag chemical tanker TINTOMARA, was transiting the Mississippi river dounbound en route to Jacksonville, Florida, when she collided with tug MEL OLIVER and barge DM-932. The Mel Oliver, transiting upbound the river and towing barge DM-932, unexpectedly altered course to port, crossing in front of TINTOMARA, which attempted to warn Mel Oliver of the impending collision via radio contact, blowing her whistle and flashing lights. In an attempt to avoid the collision the TINTOMARA altered her course to starboard, but made contact with Mel Oliver's starboard hull. No crew members sustained injuries on either vessel, but the mel Oliver sustained considerable hull damage and she spilled approximately 280,000 gallons of fuel oil as a result of the incident.

SOLASStatus: HAI YING: SOLAS, NORD POWER: SOLAS
SummaryOfEvents: On 22nd July 2008 the bulk Carrier Nord Power (Panamanian registered, 88594gt), which was sailing from Tobata, Japan to Australia, collided with the general Cargo Ship HAI YING  (Cambodian registered, 1312gt), which was en route from China to Yahata, Japan in the Kanmon Passage. As a result of the collision, HAI YING  listed to starboard 24 degrees. All her crew members were rescued.

On 20th July 2007 the chief engineer of the LION PRINCESS fell from the main mast and injured his back. It was not broken but he was in great pain and the doctor's report stated that he was unable to work and should be repatriated.

On 20th July 2008 the general cargo ship  SCAN FJELL was at sea when, at approximately 06.00 hours LT the main engine sustained damage to a cylinder liner causing cooling water and LO to overflow into the expansion tank. This rendered the ship unfit to proceed.
The vessel called for towing assistance and was subsequently towed to Cuxhaven.

REPORT DETAILING AT JULY 20 THE M/V RORO KARAM ALLAH WHICH SUFFRED ENGINE FAILURE NINE DAYS AGO, AFTER IT RAN OUT FUEL OFF THE COAST OF OMAN. THE VESSEL AND ITS 19 CREW WERE SLOWLY DRIFTING TOWARDS THE KURIA MURIA ISLANDS BEFORE SURCOUF ARRIVED.

On Friday July 18th, 2008, at approximately 16:00 hours the barge TOUAX 707 was navigating downstream along the Paraguay River from Corumba (Brazil), where she was loaded with 2670 tons of iron mineral, and was en route to San Lorenzo Port. 
During her journey she underwent a hull breakage at km 1372 (Argentinean measurement unit), and was left stranded on the Argentinean coast in a position which was not blocking other ships. 

The barge TOUAX 707 was part of a group of 12 barges which were navigating together to different destinations. The other 3 barges went through similar incidents.
At 08.51 hours LT on 15th July 2008 the bulk carrier ATLANTIC EAGLE  suffered damage to its hull after it grounded on a submerged, charted rock.

In connection with sea trials on Friday the 11th of July 2008, a large motor yacht was being towed from the building yards (AROS Maritime A/S) floating dock.

The tow consisted of two minor tugs, THOR and TYR and the motor yacht WATERLILLY.
From the floating dock WATERLILLY was to be swayed 180º and subsequently to be towed into a specified position and released from the tow.

As the sway was completed the master of WATERLILLY engaged the propellers. This caused TYR to be pulled abeam and to capsize.

The crew on TYR fell overboard but they were rescued immediately after.
Consequences1: Ship rendered unfit to proceed,Total loss of the ship

Location: IN THE VICINITY OF BOUY NO. 24
SummaryOfEvents:
At 05:10 local time on July 11th, 2008 the Panama registered vehicle carrier M/V AMITY ACE was reported to have run aground in a bank of sand (1) one mile from Racon Buoy # 24. The vessel’s actual grounding position was reported as LAT=31-06.3 N / LON= 081-27.0 W.

The vessel was on her way from Veracruz, Mexico and navigated up the Brunswick River under the Master’s orders and pilot’s advice. She was laden with cargo of vehicles (see TAB No. 15 for details on the cargo).

At about 01:30 PM on July 11th, 2008 during the high tide and with assistance of tugs, the vessel was refloated without experiencing any major damage.

The vessel proceeded on her own power up river, and berthed at Brunswick city docks at about 02:40 PM.

On 10 July 2008 the M/V Barbara was on her passage from Antwerp to Barcarena, Brazil. At the Dover Strait, when joining the South West Bound lane near the Foxtrot 3 buoy, she created a hazardous close quarter situation with the Chemical Tanker, M/T Maersk Borneo, which was sailing a South Westerly course in the shipping lane. Both vessels were on a collision course and after M/V Barbara was called upon repeatedly by M/T Maersk Borneo and by the Dover Coast Guard, M/V Barbara did not reply and failed to give way. 

To avoid a collision, M/T Maersk Borneo made a starboard 360° turn.

At 03.12 hours LT on 9th July 2008 the bulk carrier FU HUA collected pilot and at 18.00 hours LT changed pilot at pilot town.  The pilot was again changed at 01.00 hours on 10th July. At approximately 02.02 hours LT, after the pilot had ordered the rudder to port, reportedly to avoid incoming south bound traffic at position :LAT 29-52.256 N / 089-54.514  W MR MM 81.9, the vessel grounded. The draft of the vessel prior to grounding was reported as: 
FWD 13.70 M, AFT 14.00 M.
Cargo on board: iron ore approx .70, 846 M/T.
Weather condition: Cloudy skies, wind SE 4, visibility good, (7), air temperature 26 DEG celsius.
After grounding the pilot tried to reloat the vessel by repeatedly moving steering from port to starboard and back, and also by reversing engines. Finally at about 03:05 hours LT the vessel was refloated and proceeded up-river. The USCG  ordered the vessel to drop anchor at the General anchorage and restricted vessel from movement until  further notice.
In the morning hours Class (CCS) surveyor boarded vessel and inspected some of the ballast tanks and  issued a report  (copy in the file),  following which the USCG rescinded restriction and vessel proceeded to discharge anchorage.

On 6th July 2008 the m/v VARAGEN was departing Fair Isle harbour and released all mooring ropes in an attempt to clear the quay bodily by the use of her engines and bow thrusts. As she did so, the wind caught her and set the vessel down onto shallow water where the propellor made contact with the sea bed. As the vessel manoeuvered herself to clear the harbour, she made contact with the pier and damaged the rails of a yacht moored close by. Although the propellor blades were damaged, the vessel was able to depart the port and continue to her next destination.
On 5th July 2008 the bulk carrier GOLDEN STAR I was departing the port of Paradip, India, when she ran aground, under pilotage, at approximately 08.45 hours LT.
ON 4TH JULY 2008 THE ELEFTHERIA WAS SAILING DOWNRIVER IN THE EMILIO MITRE CHANNEL UNDER RIVER PILOT WITH REDUCED SPEED, WHEN HER PORT BOW CONTACTED THE PORT BOW OF VEHICULE CARRIER PACIFIC HIGHWAY.

In the port of departure, Bilbao, Spain, some leakage of thermal oil is discovered. The overflow pipe of the thermal oil tank is sweating some oil/ water. A temporary repair by means of rubber hose is applied. 8 days later, in the middle of the Atlantic Ocean a thermal oil alarm sounds. Once the engineer on duty is near the thermal oil boiler, he sees a fire in the funnel near the oil expansion tank. The fire cannot be extinguished by means of portable fire extinguisher, so CO2 is released into the engine room. Fire extinguished but severe damage to heating system. Vessel does not have sufficient MDO on board to reach a port. A tug is called in, vessel deviates on MDO for few for approaching hurricane.
Investigation revealed that several signals of water in the thermal oil have been neglected and no structural solutions has been made. Investigation revealed that overflow pipe of thermal oil tank was blocked with debris. Once a boil off occured due to water in the oil, the overpressure could not escape to the overflow tank, but found its way through the damaged pipe. A spray occured which has been ignited causing fire

The day after her delivery voyage to Milford Haven, the tug Svitzer Waterston was conducting propulsion trials with her new master onboard.  After the trials the tug headed back into port and another local tug skipper, who was onboard for familiarisation training, took the opportunity to get a feeingl for the controls.  During this time the tug left the main channel and grounded briefly in the area of Chapel Rocks. The vessel was rendered unfit to proceed.

On 2nd July 2008 the general cargo ship ROSETHORN was in The Sound and had just passed the Drogden dredged channel heading northbound when she ran aground at approximately 02.00 hours LT. The duty officer had to steer, navigate and perform anti-collision maneouvres himself. When he had to give way for another vessel, the duty officer lost awareness of the vessel's exact position, and she grounded outside the fairway.

On 1st July 2008 the m/v THE TOISA CONQUEROR was undergoing repairs in port.  Two soft patches, one in the main deck, had been removed to allow removal of one of the main engines.  A shore side worker was grinding the edge of one of the soft patches ready for its rewelding into the deck.  The soft patch had been placed near by the opening left in the deck. At approximately 1811 on 29 June 2008, the ro-ro cargo ship Moondance was shifting from a lay-by berth to the ferry linkspan in Warrenpoint Harbour, Northern Ireland.  At 18:13 she grounded on the south-western bank of Carlingford Lough following an electrical blackout. There were no injuries, but the ship suffered severe distortion of the port and starboard rudder stocks.

At 03:20 hours on 29 June 2008, the general cargo ship Antari grounded on the coast of Northern Ireland, while on passage from Corpach, Scotland to Ghent, Belgium, The officer of the watch had fallen asleep shortly after taking over the watch at midnight when the ship was passing the peninsula of Kintyre (Scotland). With no-one awake  on the bridge, the ship continued on for over 3 hours, crossing the North Channel of the Irish sea before grounding on a gently sloping beach about 7 miles north of Larne.

SummaryOfEvents:
Le samedi 28 Juin 2008, peu avant minuit, le cargo roulier français MN Eider et le chalutier sénégalais Adja Ndoumbe III sont contrebordiers au large de la  Gambie, à moins de 90 miles dans le Sud  de Dakar. Le MN Eider manœuvre pour passer à 1 mille de l’Adja NDoumbe III, craignant  une situation trop rapprochée, abat alors sur sa droite. Malgré la manœuvre  de dernière  minute effectuée  par l’Eider, la collision se produit à 00:15 heures le 29 juin 2008. Le navire de pêche chavire et coule 35 minute après.
Le MN Eider porte assistance au navire de pêche et son équipage est récupéré sain et sauf.

La nuit de l’accident  les conditions météorologiques sont maniables : à minuit  le 28 juin 2008, l’officier de quart du roulier note au journal  de bord un vent d’Ouest de force  5, une mer agitée et une bonne visibilité.

SECCIÓN 1. - “CONTEXTO Y CIRCUNSTANCIAS EN QUE OCURRIÓ  EL SINIESTRO”.


La M/N Chilena “Tacora”  es una nave Granelera,  construida el año 1985 en Japón, la cual por años ha sido operada en el transporte de hierro, utilizando el muelle mecanizado de la Compañía Minera del Pacífico, CMP., entre otros. 

Su Armador corresponde a una prestigiosa compañía chilena que opera habitualmente con varias naves para el transporte de hierro, desde los puertos de embarque en la III y IV regiones. La nave aún cuando tiene más de 20 años, está en buen estado de mantención.

Previo al siniestro, el “Tacora” había terminado el embarco de 24.976 toneladas métricas de graneles en el puerto de “Huasco” y los operadores habían considerado que se dirigiera a Coquimbo para embarcar 12.000 toneladas métricas de granza.

Dicha travesía comenzó a las 09:20 horas del día 26 de junio de 2008,  zarpando a las 05:30 horas, con destino al muelle mecanizado de Guayacán, navegación que se realizó sin inconvenientes y con buenas condiciones de mar y viento, arribando a los límites del puerto el mismo 27 a las 15:12 horas, momento en el cual la bahía presentaba brisa moderada del SW y 10 nudos. 

El buque considerablemente cargado, llegó al punto de embarco de práctico con la máquina muy despacio avante, a una velocidad de entre 5 y 6 nudos, sobrepasando en al menos 2 o 3 nudos la velocidad de seguridad fijada para aproximar al  puerto.
El práctico lo abordó por medio de una lancha que se abarloó con dificultad al “Tacora”, debido a la elevada velocidad que este llevaba en su aproximación. 

El práctico al llegar al puente paró la máquina y cayó para tomar  la enfilación de fondeo, pero al llegar al nuevo rumbo, el 112° y a pesar de estar ya la caña cerrada a la banda contraria para aguantar la caída, la nave continuó cayendo lentamente a babor, quedando en rumbo de colisión con el muelle y aproximadamente a 4 cables del mismo. 

El práctico indicó al capitán su decisión de dar atrás para parar la viada, el capitán discrepa e indica al práctico la conveniencia de dar paladas avante para botar la proa a estribor y salir de la demarcación de colisión con el muelle. 

Se ordenó a la máquina despacio avante, lo que efectivamente se materializó por un lapso estimado de medio minuto, sin embargo la nave siguió avanzando en rumbo de colisión al muelle, no cayó a estribor como se esperaba e incrementó levemente su velocidad de aproximación al muelle.

El práctico decidió abortar el atraque y no fondear el ancla por considerarlo peligroso debido a la velocidad con que aproximan, ordenando al remolcador Ultramar XI cambiar de banda para carnerear por la amura de babor, a fin de botar la proa hacia estribor. Conjuntamente ordenó “parar la máquina” y después dar “atrás media fuerza”. 

El capitán segundos más tarde ordenará “toda fuerza atrás” y posteriormente “repetido atrás”. 
Dado el poco tiempo de maniobra disponible, el remolcador no alcanza a actuar eficazmente y la nave finalmente colisiona de proa con el extremo Norte del muelle mecanizado CMP, lo que provoca daños en la nave y en la estructura portuaria.

Producto del accidente, no se registraron lesiones a personas, ni contaminación al medio ambiente marino y los daños se circunscribieron a  rotura y abolladuras del casco, en el sector superior del bulbo y a la altura del void space, comprometiendo la integridad de estanques de lastre, al quedar estos abiertos por la proa,  posibilitando el embarque de  agua de mar. 

La estabilidad de la nave no fue afectada, sin embargo en consideración al tipo de daños en el casco, debió ser sometida a reparaciones de fortuna, a la gira en la bahía y posteriormente con apoyo de astillero las definitivas en Talcahuano. 

El Muelle sufrió daños estructurales, pero pudo continuar operando con restricciones.

As a result of the collision, SHOTOKU MARU No.15 sustained a hole, causing a small water ingress. She was towed to dockyard. All her crew were not injured.

On June 25th 2008 at approximately 01.30 hours LT a fire broke out in the engine room of the Liberian Flag container vessel REUNION as she was berthing at Jakarta. The engine was shut off, the ventilators and quick closing valves were closed and the crew fought the fire with extinguishers. After the engine room had become full of smoke and extremely hot, the crew evacuated the engine room, sealed it and released the CO2 fixed fire fighting system to extinguish the fire. At approximately 06.00 hours LT the engine room had cleared of smoke, and entrance was permitted. Although no external assistance was required to control the fire, three tugs assisted the REUNION to berth as she was operating without power. Flag state investigation was conducted by obtaining the flag state report and follow-up communications for clarification after review, as necessary.
At 20.00 hours LT on 24th June 2006 the bulk carrier DEVPRAYAG was departing the port of Lyttelton, New Zealand, when her mooring rope snapped, resulting in fatal injury to a shore linesman.

The auxiliary engine #1 was in normal operation when suddenly the engine speed increased significantly and the engine started running very roughly with a lot of vibration. Despite several attempts at stopping the engine it kept running, and the exhaust pipe became red hot. The heat was so intense that various equipment in the vicinity started smoking and melting.  When some material started igniting and the engine was still out of control, it was decided to evacuate the engine room and activate the stationary foam extinguishing system. The foam extinguished the fire and prevented further ignition, and when the engine finally stopped after having consumed all its lubricating oil, the situation was under control. There was minimal damage to light fixtures etc. from the fire, but both auxiliary engine and generator were destroyed.

The fishing vessel ATILUKOQ was fishing crabs south of Disko Island. During setting out a buoy rope a crew member, 17 years of age, was caught by a loop on his left leg.

The crew member clung to the gunwale for a moment while another crew member hurried in vain to fetch a knife to cut the rope.

The crew member was pulled overboard. The other crew member and the skipper fetched the rope, but they were note able to pull him back. A little later the rope became slack and when they hauled it in, they ascertained that the crew member himself had cut the rope with a pocket knife.

The crew member who had fallen overboard was not found.

Location: Government cut by port of Miami
SummaryOfEvents:
MV Rio Haina was outward bound with pilot on board from port of Miami. There was a blackout on board due to failure of all her generators at government cut when she was to first turn to port and then to starboard. As the generators had failed at 0048 hours on 22nd jun’08, the main engines also tripped due to sea water pumps tripping off. The Master pilot  let go the starboard anchor to slow down the vessel as well as stop the vessel.

But it was too late and the vessel collided with Marina wharf concrete wall at about 08 knots speed and grounded from forward till collision bulk head. 

The seawall of Marina wharf and its concrete pilings were damaged. 

The vessel and marina wharf was inspected by the US coast guard. The vessel was inspected for any underwater damages. The anchor was cut as it could damage the cables running underwater off the Marina beach.

The vessel was then towed to the Antillean berth, Miami for inspection and repairs on 24th June’2008 with the help of 3 tugs. The anchor was later recovered by the diving company. 
There was no serious damage to the vessel.

SummaryOfEvents: On 21st June 2008 a seaman fitter was working unsupervised on a partially opened hatch cover aboard the container ship VARMLAND, when he fell to his death. He had not been wearing a safety harness and no barriers were in place by the unprotected opening.

SOLASStatus: MV PRINCESS OF THE STARS": Unknown/unspecified"
SummaryOfEvents: The ro-ro ferry PRINCESS OF THE STARS departed Manila, Philippines, on the evening of 20 June 2008, bound for Cebu City, Philippines, with hundreds of passengers on board.  The ferry sent a distress signal at midday on 21 June 2008 when its engines stalled in rough seas near Sibuyan. The ship capsized at the height of the typhoon "Frank" (International Code Name: Fengshen) in an area approximately 1,500 metres off the coast of Sitio Cabitangahanan, Barangay Taclobo, San Fernando, Romblon, Philippines, with the loss of many lives.

Location: Off the 'Varne' bank in the Dover Strait
SummaryOfEvents: At 11:25 hours on 21 June 2008, a diver entered the water from the Belgium registered self-propelled crane barge Norma in order to replace a line marking the position of the wreck of a German submarine which had been sunk during World War One off the “Varne” bank in the Dover Strait. As the diver descended to a depth of about 20 metres, the umbilical cord containing an air supply became entangled in the ship’s aft Voith Schneider propeller, and the diver was dragged towards its rotating blades. The diver’s air supply was also pulled from the deck but the diver succeeded in transferring to a bottled air supply before it severed. The diver was approximately 3 metres from the rotating propeller when the propeller was stopped by the vessel’s chief engineer. The diver then managed to cut himself free and make his way to the surface from where he was recovered without injury.

On 20th June 2008 the M/V SAGA was underway from Uddevalla to Dubai. Due to the dimensions of the vessel no pilot was required outbound from Uddevalla. However, after passing Älgö inside Marstrandsfjorden the vessel ran aground at rock beacon Hunden at approximately 21.30 hours LT.  After the grounding a pilot was sent to SAGA and she arrived alongside at Älgö for inspection and later sailed back to Uddevalla.

Location: About 10km East from Tsumekisaki, Shizuoka Prefecture, Japan
SummaryOfEvents:
Container Ship JI FENG (Hong Kong registered, 5601gt) , travelling from Kakogawa to Chiba, and General Cargo ship TAKASAGO No.2 (Japanese registered, 298gt), en route from Tokyo to Nagoya, were involved in a collision about 10km East from Tsumekisaki, Shizuoka Prefecture, Japan at 0845 hours on June 20, 2008.
As a result of the collision, TAKASAGO No.2 sunk, but all her crew were rescued. JI FENG sustained a minor damage to its bow and all her crew were not injured.

A dredger was preparing to berth in an east of England port for small repairs to the hull shell plating while in the ballasted condition.  The bow thruster was running in the "Thrust 2" setting when the vessel suffered a blackout when about 150 metres from the dockside.  The vessel was stopped using its main engines and a spring which was connected to the dockside.

Investigations found that the bow thruster motor had overheated and the generator supply breaker had tripped out on overcurrent causing the blackout.  Further investigations revealed that the bow thruster motor had recently been overhauled and the slip rings at the "Thrust two" position had been incorrectly secured resulting in one of the electrical phases being lost.  This meant that the motor was single phasing causing excess current to be drawn.  The over current and timing settings on the bow thruster supply breaker were set at about 600 amps and 20 seconds as approved by Lloyds.  This meant that the lower amperage and timing of the generator supply breaker acted first tripping the breaker and causing the blackout
It is noted that the bow thruster motors are made by the Dutch Company - Becker and have caused trouble for some time.  The operating company ahave adjusted breaker settings in accordance with advice from Lloyds, in addition the resistor banks had been operating very close to their maximum rating.  An alternative, higher rating resistor bank, has been approved by Class and was fitted during dry docking week commencing 6 October.

At 15.55 hours on 18th June 2008 the Asphalt tanker ID PARTNER (Panamanian Registered, 998gt) ran ground after leaving the East No.1 pier, Kashiwazaki, Niigata Prefecture, Japan in lat 37 22.6N, long 138 32.5E. The vessel was towed by a work boat and refloated on the same day. No water ingress, oil spill, or personal injury has been reported.
On 17th June 2008 the tug CHALLENGER collided with Beacon No.1 North in the channel of Doha Port, Qatar.

Location: in open sea, nearest port Mumbai, India
SummaryOfEvents: On 16th June 2008 the general cargo ship TRUBEZH sailed from Dharamtar at 15.55 hours LT en route to Mundra, carrying 847.9 Mt of sulphur in jumbo bags. At 21.45 hours LT in position 18.53.70 N, 072 20.2E, the engine control room reported that the temperature of #2 unit of auxiliary engine No. 1 was high, and it should be stopped after the changeover of fuel from HO to DO. The main engine was stopped at 22.15 hours and the port anchor was dropped at 23.20 hours LT at position: 18.53.81N; 072.18.398E. The master informed the owners that the ship needed to be towed, and two tugs were  were sent out on 17 June 2008, but the operation was aborted due to severe weather conditions. On 1st July 2008 the vessel anchored safely at inner Mumbai Harbour at 16.40 hours LT to carry out repairs to the main engine and auxiliary generators. The vessel was inspected at Mumbai under Port State Control Regime and detained due to serious deficiencies.

The tanker CHAMPION BRALI collided with passenger vessel TOPAZ on 10 June 2008 at 08.13 hours local time at the Outside Port Limit near Eastern Petroleum Anchorage. The vessel was loaded with Palm Oil to be discharged at Turkey from Pasir Gudang, Malaysia. There were no casualties and no pollition. When investigators attended the vessel was anchored and floating with a full cargo of Palm Oil. The other vessel was at anchor during the collision.

On 11 June 2008, a motorman found an experienced found an experienced petty officer lying at the bottom of a ballast tank on boa	rd the passenger cruise ship Saga Rose while the ship was visiting Southampton, UK. The petty officer was the vessel’s second bosun who had been sent to the tank to determine whether it contained fresh or salt water. The motorman raised the alarm and then returned to the scene and entered the tank to help the petty officer, who was a close friend. The motorman then also collapsed.
The onboard emergency response team quickly arrived with breathing apparatus, and the local emergency services were called to assist. The motorman was successfully revived and evacuated from the tank but the second bosun died before he could be recovered.

Location: Off Noto peninsula, Ishikawa Prefecture, Japan
SummaryOfEvents: On 9th June 2008 the bulk Carrier TKB Takano (St.Kitts/Nevis registered, 3127gt, built 1979), was en route from Nanao, Ishikawa, Japan to Vladivostok, Russia. Due to engine malfunction she became unnavigable in lat 37 28.5N, long 137 23.4E. The crew were unable to repair the damage and the vessel was subsequently towed to Nanao port on June 10.
ClassificationSociety1: Polski Rejestr Statkow (Polish Register of Shipping) (PRS)

SummaryOfEvents: On 5th June 2008 the the general cargo ship FULMAR had left Zeebrugge and was steering Westerly through the Wandelaar Pilot precautionary area. As FULMAR entered the area the m/v Cap Bisti left the anchorage to the North and was proceeding to pick up a pilot. Cap Bisti was not at first detected in the anchorage area and when she was  the capabilities of the azipod drive were misunderstood and attempts to go astern resulted in a slow shear to port (towards Cap Bisti) and the bow of FULMAR collided with the port side, amidships, of Cap Bisti

The ro-ro cargo ship WIND SOLUTION  had been in port for 6 weeks, carrying out remedial work following re-flagginfg surveys. Sailing for the first time with all new crew, the master and pilot agreed that the master should take the ship off the quay and turn her, and then the pilot would take over to negotiate the locks. The Master moved the ship off the quay and parallel to it and then started to turn. The stern swung to port and collided with the quay, dislodging a pair of bollards as it sacraped 30 metres down the quay before the pilot could regain control. Departure then completed without incident until pilot boat coxwain notified pilot and master of hole in port quarter. The Master decided to return to port for repairs.

On June 2nd 2008 at approximately 00.05 hours LT, the Liberian flag reefer vessel CARIBBEN STAR was discharging her cargo of used cars at the port of Douala, when stevedores tried to start the engine of a car using wires from external batteries. This resulted in a short circuit and possible leak of benzine, and a fire broke out in the cargo hold No. 4. The hold was immediately sealed and the vessel used the CO2 fixed fire fighting system to control the fire. The Douala Port control notified the local fire department and tug Douala Mango Bell in case further assistance was necessary. The fire was controlled, the discharge resumed and the vessel was duly inspected by the local port authorities and the vessel's crew. There were no injuries reorted. Flag state investigation was conducted by obtaining the flag state report and follow-up communications for clarifications after review, as necessary.

Location: Nothwest of the Wittow, Rugen Peninsula
SummaryOfEvents:
On the morning of 1 June 2008 the ship Artur Becker, operating under the German flag, was on an expedition voyage with passengers, 1.5 nautical miles northwest of the wittow, Rugen peninsula. After the Arthur Becker had anchored west of Wittow for the precious night, she weighed anchor at 06:09 hours. The aim of the voyage was to visit a shipwreck north of Rugen. The weather conditions were good. The bridge was managed by the master, the technical officer and a helmsman. At around 06:30 hours, a freight ship was observed from the port side, the Raba operating under the polish flag. She was on her way with a cargo of grain from Boston, Great Britain to Szczecin, Poland. Her bridge was managed by a polish chief officer.
When the two ships approached each other, the Raba called the Arthur Becker on the VHF; they tried to reach an agreement for manoeuvring, but in doing so a misunderstanding resulted. The two ships collided bow to bow at approximately 06:45 hours, and as a result the Arthur Becher then hit the Raba with her port side. Both ships received material damage above the water line. The ships were able to continue under their own power.
No persons were injured because of the accident, nor did any environmentally hazardous substances leak.
ClassificationSociety1: Polski Rejestr Statkow (Polish Register of Shipping) (PRS)

SOLASStatus: KAIJU MARU: Unknown/unspecified, SITC YANTAI: Unknown/unspecified
Location: In Hakata Port, Fukuoka Prefecture, Japan
SummaryOfEvents:
Cargo ship KAIJU MARU (registered Japan, 199gt) with 3 crew (all Japanese) collided with container ship SITC YANTAI (registered Tuvalu, 4496gt) with 20 crew (all Chinese) in Hakata Port, Fukuoka Prefecture, Japan.
As result of the collision, KAIJU MARU capsized, but all her crew were rescued. She sustained a hole in the port midship. Oil leaked from her, creating an oil slick about 500m long and 10m wide. SITC YANTAI sustained a dent in the bulbous bow and got a scratch on her starboard.

Location: Gulf of Suez, Ras Shukheir, Egypt
SummaryOfEvents:
At 05:12 hours (UTC + 3) on 30 May 2008  the Norfolk Express carrying 1170 containers, on a voyage from Giola Tauro (Italy) to Jebeil (United Arab Emirates) run aground before sunrise at Ras Shukheir (Egypt) in the Gulf of Suez. Nobody was injured and no pollutants escaped. The wind was coming from NW with a strength of 4 Bft. Wisibility was good and good and the torches of the oil fields lit up the environment.
Norfolk Express was running at a speed of 21 kn along the southern edge of the traffic separation scheme and according to the voyage planning should have carried out course changes at 04:35 and 04:51 hours in the direction of traffic. At the handling over of the watch at 04:00 hours, the traffic situation had been explained and also that two course changes and overtaking manoeuvres were to be expected in the immediate future. Another ship on the same course had been ahead at a distance of 2 nm. A second ship was ahead at a distance of 4 nm. No further close approaches could be seen and traffic appeared to be running smoothly. As a consequence the Officer on watch decided to dismiss the lookout to carry out cleaning works in the superstructures.

After this the Officer on watch proceeded to the radio station that is located starboard aft next to the chart table. There he read his emails on the computer and in between observed the radar display. His thoughts had been very occupied and later he could no longer remember exactly what happen up to the accident. The Vessel Traffic Service had suddenly called and drawn attention to the danger of stranding.
Thereupon he had proceeded to the radar set and ascertained that speed was being reduced. In his estimation it was now too late to alter course with strong rudder manoeuvres or to check the position on the chart. Intuitively he put the engine telegraph to stop. He then set the Norfolk Express gently aground.

Location: 10km off Atsumi Peninsula, Aichi Prefecture, Japan
SummaryOfEvents: On 28th May 2008 the vehicle carrier ARTEMIS LEADER (registered Panama, 62400gt built 2008) became unnavigable 10 km off Atsumi Peninsula, Aichi Prefecture, Japan, due to engine trouble. The vessel was towed to port by a local tug for repairs.

Location: Bruce Mines, North Channel, Lake Huron, Ontario
SummaryOfEvents: On the morning of 28 May 2008 at 05:49 hours eastern daylight time, while approaching the Ontario Trap Rock loading facility near Bruce Mines, Ontario, the bulk carrier Algomarine ran aground on a charted shoal. The ship had extensive damage but was refloated. There was no pollution.

ON 24TH MAY 2008 THE TANKER "JOSE BRIGHT" WAS AT HOUSTON FAIRWAY ANCHORAGE WHEN TWO ABLE BODIED SEAMEN WERE TAKEN ILL. 
THE FIRST WAS MR. AUNG NYI NYI MAUNG, WHO COMPLAINED OF DIZZINESS AND VOMITING AT 13:30 HOURS LT.  THE MASTER INFORMED USCG THROUGH THE AGENT.  FIRT AID TREATMENT WAS GIVEN AS PER THE GUIDELINES UP UNTIL 01.05 HOURS LT THE FOLLOWING DAY. AT 01:10 LOCAL TIME, THE PATIENT WAS DISCHARGED FROM VESSEL AND WAS HOSPITALIZED IN ST. JOSEPH MEDICAL CENTRE, HOUSTON.
THE PATIENT WAS UNCONSCIOUS AND THE CAUSE OF HIS ILLNESS WAS UNKNOWN.

IN THE SECOND CASE, MR. TAHUNG HTAIK WAS FOUND COLLAPSED ON HIS CABIN FLOOR
AT 13.30 HOURS LT.  THE MASTER AND THE OFFICER IMMEDIATELY ATTENDED THE SCENE, AND AN INITIAL INSPECTION REVEALED BLEEDING FROM THE NOSE, NO PULSE RATE AND BODY STIFFENED.
THE AUTHORITY (USCG) WAS INFORMED THROUGH THE AGENT AND A RESCUE TEAM ARRIVED SHORTLY AFTERWARDS.  AFTER AN EXAMINATION, USCG CONFIRMED THAT MR. THAUNG HTAIK WAS DEAD.
THE CAUSE OF HIS DEATH COULD NOT BE DETERMINED.

On May 23th 2008 at 06:30 PM the Vessel Aoun Allah struck the quay during mooring manouevre in Pozzallo harbour.
The vessel demaged some fender and the quay and has undergone a hole in the bow and hawsehole.
During departure erraneously a buoy is passed on the wrong side. Vessel aground with severe bottom damage.

On 23rd May 2008 the Greek container vessel MAERSK MANDRAKI was en route from Shanghai to Yantian when at about 14.00 hours LT she collided with the fishing vessel “ZHEXIANGYU 46048”,  owned by Chen Delang. The accident caused the fishing boat  to sink, but all crew were rescued and there were no missing or dead.

The vessel, MV Hakone, arrived in Shanghai, China at 1340hrs (All times are local time) on 5th May 2008, and entered into Huaran Dadong Dockyard at 1500hrs on 6th May 2008 for her five-year-term special inspection and repairing as required by Class. 
At around 1300hrs on 22nd May, the blow test of CO2 fixed fire extinguishing system line into cargo holds with 7k/cm2 air was successfully carried out by the ship’s crew. 
At around 1400hrs, the crew started preparation into the test of Engine room. At around 1545hrs, the test was conducted with 7kg/cm2. However, it was unsuccessful. The crew noticed that the air pressure was not sufficient, and decided to use more 25kg/cm2 high pressure air system which was installed in the CO2 room originally. 
At around 1610hrs, the valve of 25kg/cm2 of the compressed air was opened by the crew.
At around 1615hrs, the crew realized that the CO2 bottle was released by the compressed air with laud sound accidentally. 
At around 1619hrs, the master mustered a crewmembers emergency station, and commenced rescue operation. A shore 

rescue team was requested at same time. 
At around 1625hrs, the shore rescue team arrived, and started the rescue operation. 
At around 1710hrs, suffered thirteen (13) crews and three (3) shore workers were sent to a hospital. 
At around 1820hrs, the master confirmed no personnel remained in the engine room, and all other crew was not injured. 
At around 1930hrs, the superintendent confirmed three (3) crew fatalities in the hospital. 
Five (5) injured crews were discharged hospital on 25th May, and went back to the vessel. And other five (5) crews were 

discharged on 31st May, and repatriated on 1st June. And three (3) shore workers were discharged on the same day as well

At approximately 11.09 hours LT on May 22nd 2008 the M/V “RONG PENG”, which is owned by Rongcheng Marine Transportation Company Ltd.,  collided with M/V “HANJIN 3005”, owned by HANJIN Transportation Co. Ltd.  There was negligible damage sustained by the RONG PENG, but  the HANJIN 3005's portside bulwark collapsed, and a hollow hole was created about two metres above the water line.

The vessel RUDOKOP collided with the one-man operated fishing vessel ATLANTIC. Both vessels were steaming. RUDOKOP towards Gdynia for the shipyard and ATLANTIC for homeport after having finished fishing. ATLANTIC foundered, but the skipper is rescued by a nearby colleague.
On 21st May 2008 the Iranian-flagged general cargo ship FARAZ was in collision with the United Arab Emirates-flagged barge MERU in the channel off Doha Port, Qatar.

1.  At about 1429 on 19 May 2008, at the approximately position lat. 15-39.0’N, long. 110-44.6’E, a lifeboat accident happened onboard the Hong Kong registered container ship BLUE OCEAN while she was en-route from Hong Kong to Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam. 
2.  During a boat drill on the No. 2 Lifeboat at sea, the Third Officer who was accompanied by a seaman inside the lifeboat, pulled the remote control cable to lower the boat by the order of the Master. The lifeboat swung out from the lifeboat davit. 
3.  The Master ordered the Third Officer to lower the lifeboat further, but the cable was found jammed. The Third Officer asked the seaman to help him pull the cable together. Suddenly, the lifeboat descended rapidly and plunged into the water, rebounded, swung towards and hit the shipside and was damaged. Water rushed ran into the lifeboat and flushed the Third Officer to the sea. 
4.  The Master of BLUE OCEAN conducted a search and rescue operation for the Third Officer and the seaman. The seaman inside the No.2 Lifeboat was rescued but the Third Officer was still missing. The SAR operation for the missing Third Officer conducted by BLUE OCEAN alone continued until 1300 on 20 May 2008, but it was in vain. After that, the Master recovered the No.2 Lifeboat and resumed the voyage to Ho Chi Minh City.

On 18 May 2008 the container ship Ruiloba, flying the Spanish flag, was en route from Hamburg to Bremerhaven and headed for Terminal CT 4 on the Stromkaje, with her port side. The westerly wind came from starboard, more from astern than from abeam, with a strength of 3-4 Bft and ebb tide ran against the ship at 3 – 3.5 Kn. The mooring manoeuvres were controlled from the port bridge wing. In the wing were the Master, Second Officer, a Service-engineer and the Harbour Pilot. The mooring was carried out without any problem. During this, the helm and the engine controls, including the transverse thrusters, were operated by the Second Officer according to the recommendation of the Pilot. The Ruiloba should be moored with three bow lines and three stern lines respectively as well as two fore springs and two aft springs. After all the lines were fixed on land, Bremerhaven Port was notified that the Ruiloba had moored at 18:10 hours. Afterwards the Second Officer accompanied the Pilot to the aft deck. There the tugboat was still attached with a loose towline to starboard. On the starboard pilot ladder the Pilot noticed an unusual turning of the Ruiloba to port and so he went back to the bridge. There the Master reported that from the port wing no movement of the Ruiloba could be detected anymore. The ship however laid approximately 7 metres distance from the pier at the stern. The tugboat was instructed to push the stern of the ship back to the pier again. After this the Ruiloba was about 5-6 meters further south than its original position. Through the forward movement and the veering away of the stern, a stern line and one fore and one aft spring each were broken. Because of this, two seamen were gravely injured on the legs.

On May 17th 2008 at about 1.204 hours LT the container ship “DE SHAN”(flying Chinese flag and owned by JiangSu RuiHaoXiang International logistics Co.Ltd from Shanghai) was en route to Bayuquan when she collided with the general cargo/semi-container ship “MEDI TRADITION”(flying Panama flag) owned by Hong Kong TRANCO LIMITED at position 37°51′.7N/122°15′.7E (north Huanghai sea). The m/v. DE SHAN sank immediately, but there were no injuries or fatalities. Some pollution of the sea was caused.

On 17th May 2008 the general cargo ship MCL TRADER  grounded at full speed in fair weather. The bridge was unmanned and the vessel failed to alter course in accordance with the Voyage Plan approximately one hour before the grounding. The vessel re-floated on its own 15 hours later, during rising water. The vessel sustained dents to its bottom and a small leakage in a water bottom tank.

On the evening of 16 May 2008, the ferry Finnlady, sailing under Finnish flag, put into the Travemünde ferry port. She was operating a line service between Helsinki/Finland and Travemünde. The intention was to moor up as usual, with the stern at pier 6 of the Skandinavinkai. The weather and visibility conditions were good, and there was a prevailing east-north-easterly wind with a force of around 3 Bft.

On the board the Finnlady were 175 passengers, 34 crew members and a Pilot. The Master, the Chief Officer and the Pilot were on the bridge. The Second Officer was standing by at stern for the mooring manoeuvre at the mooring station. The Chief Engineer and the Second Engineer were on duty in the engine control room.


Once she had put into the port, the Finnlady turned at around 19:45 hours inside the turning basin provided. At 19:46 hours, a control failure alarm for the starboard controllable pitch propeller (CPP) system was output both on the bridge and in the engine control room. This was not initially attributed on the bridge. The ferry then shortly afterwards headed at up to 4.8 kts across the stern port towards the bridge structure at pier 6, some 5.5 cable away. The master was navigating from the port-side bridge conning position. The actual pitch of the two propellers was "Astern 2-3" corresponding to a pitch of approximately 25%. As of 1949, when the Master set the telegraphs to zero pitch in order to hold the ship and then to "Ahead" the pitch display for the starboard propeller still remain on "Astern".  However, as the port-side propeller was set to an "Ahead" pitch, the stern of the ferry swung out to port. After a call to the engine control room, the "Re-Connect" button was pressed on the bridge.  The steering control was also switched back to the central conning position. At 19:52 hours, the starboard propeller could be controlled again. However, by that time, they were just a few metres between the stern and the pier, meaning that, a minute later, the Finnlady hit the pier loading bridge at a residual astern speed of 3.4 kts.


Despite the significant impact speed, nobody was injured. There was also no leakage of substances harmful to the environment.

On 16 May 2008, the Latvian flagged general cargo ship KEGUMS, was en route from port of Sundalsora (Norway) to the port of Rostock (Germany) with aluminium ingots cargo in the hold and container cargo on deck (cargo total - : 3695,816 mt).

At approximately 15.10 hours (UTC+2), after disembarking the pilot (about 2 nm before Kristiansund pilot station), the vessel ran aground. The vessel sustained double bottom plate and structural frame damages. Nobody on board was injured and no environmental damage was caused.

On 15.05.2008 at 11.30 hours LT the master of the MSC DENISSE was informed by the chief engineer that there was ingress of water in the engine room coming from the main sea water pipeline through the ballast valve. Bilge pump was put to service to transfer this water to bilge holding tanks. Ballast pump was also started sea to sea to reduce ingress of water. Company management office was informed accordingly to carry out the necessary repairs. Company in return informed the engineer that the vessel's position about 16 nm from nearest platform of Bombay High oilfields, and so the vessel altered course to 207 (T) at vessel’s speed of 19 knots. 

At 13.30 hours LT the vessel was at a safe distance of 35 nm from nearest oil rig. Vessel engine was stopped and the arrangements to carry out repairs by fabricating blanks were carried out. The ship’s management committee of master, chief engineer, chief officer and second engineer discussed the work to be performed. 
At 14.00 hours LT the vessel's engine was stopped and repairs were commenced. All sea suction valves were closed and electric power was supplied from deck auxiliary engine. All valves on the ballast line were shut. Chief Engineer confirmed that there was no noticeable leakage hence the removal of leaking valve was carried out. 

At 17.00 hours LT while the blank was being fitted to replace the valve, water suddently started  gushing through the valve opening. The blank slipped out of place due to the excessive pressure of incoming water. Bilge pump was started to transfer water into bilge holding tank but there was no control over the ingress of water which rose at 1 cm every twenty minutes. 
The management office of the vessel was informed and their instructions were followed to close sea chest,  and shut overboard discharge valves. The main sea water pump was started sea to sea to confirm the sea chest valves were holding. 

At 19.40 hours LT the emergency bilge suction was also opened to build down the water level, but the water level remained almost constant. 
At 22.40 hours LT the Indian coast guard vessel “ Vijaya” was alongside with three submersible pumps for pumping out water from engine room. 

On 16-05-2008 at 00.15 hours the shore submersible pump was started. 
At 02.00 hours the water level had receded by 50 cm below engine room lower platform. 
By 03.30 hours LT the blank was fitted in place on pipeline. 
At 04.00 hours the pumping out of water continued, with ballast pumps as well as engine room bilge pumps. Work started on main engine sump cleaning and overhauling of pumps which were damaged due to flooding and showed very low insulation of electric motors. 

By 06.00 hours the water level had receded below pumpable level 

At 08.00 hours the Coast guard left vessel and vessel continued repairs in engine room

On 17-05-2008 at 08.00 hours the vessel resumed voyage to her next port of call, Mundra, Gujarat, India

SOLASStatus: COSTA ATLANTICA: Unknown/unspecified, GRAND NEPTUNE: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents:
At 02:57 hours on 15 May 2008, the Panamanian registered car carrier, Grand Neptune, was on passage in the Dover Strait Traffic Separation Scheme when she was manœuvred hard to starboard and completed a 360° turn to avoid the Italian registered passenger cruise ship Costa Atlantica. Costa Atlantica was on voyage from Le Havre to Harwich with 1697 passengers on board at a speed of 16 knots.
The accident occurred as the passenger ship crossed the separation scheme between MSC Serena and Grand Neptune, both of which were transiting the south-west traffic lane at speeds of 18 and Neptune and 17 knots respectively. The distance between the south-west bound ships was less than 3nm.

On 14th May 2008 the m/v KEMIRA GAS was overtaking the chemical tanker Lycian when she ran aground as a result of her manouevres. The Lycian continued her navigation towards her own destination whilst the KEMIRA GAS' lost situational awareness of her own exact position. The KEMIRA GAS was not equipped with an ECDIS-system, and when the situation changed unexpectedly, the OOW (who was only navigational officer on the bridge) lost situational awareness about own vessels exact position.

SOLASStatus: ROSA DI MAGGIO: Unknown/unspecified, TRIDENT STAR: SOLAS
SummaryOfEvents: The M/V ‘TRIDENT STAR’ Panama flag with IMO No. 9343211, on 13 May 2008 during navigation from Falconara (Italy) to Alexandria (Egypt), was involved in a probable collision with the Italian fishing boat ‘ROSA DI MAGGIO’.  The fishing boat sunk and the crew members were rescued. For M/V ‘TRIDENT STAR’ no crew members injured or damages occurred

At 16:19 hours on 12 May 2008, the Netherlands registered dry cargo ship, CFL Performer ran aground on Haisborougn Sand off the east coast of England. She was refloated 15 minutes later and continued on passage to Grimsby, River Humber, there were no injuries or damage to the ship, and there was no pollution.

At 05.41 hours on 9th May 2008 the container ship FRANCOISE GILOT grounded while departing Port Phillip. The ship had a pilot on board and the helmsman put the helm to starboard instead of port and the error was not identified until it was too late to recitify. The master was able to refloat the ship about two hours after the grounding. The ship suffered no damage and there was no pollution.

On 4th May 2008 at 07.25 hours (UTC+3) passenger cruise vessel “MONA LISA” ran aground in the Irbe Strait about 10 miles off the north coast of Latvia in position: LAT 57° 45’ N; LONG 021° 43’ E.
The vessel was on voyage from Gdynia, Poland, to Riga, Latvia, with a total ship complement of 811 cruise passengers and 327 crew. 
There was no pollution resulting from the grounding. No injuries were reported to passengers or crew.
Several attempts were made to pull the vessel free with the vessel’s 2 engines working astern and with the assistance of 4 tugs but the refloating attempts failed.
On 5th May all passengers and 23 crew were evacuated from the ship by Latvian naval vessels and safely taken to Ventspils, from where they were later taken by train to Riga for repatriation.
Refloating attempts continued during 5th – 6th May but without success.
The vessel was eventually refloated with the help of 4 tugs on 7th May at 15.12 hours and she proceeded to Ventspils, escorted by a tug, for a dive survey and class inspection.
On 7th May at 19.55 hours the vessel arrived at berth No. 37, Port of Ventspils.
An underwater inspection was carried out at Ventspils and noted that both propellers were “found to have small cracks 5 – 10 cm. A Condition of Class was imposed 
The vessel was given permission by the classification society LR for a single voyage to Kiel. The vessel sailed from Ventspils on 8th May 2008.
The cause of the grounding was a navigational error on the part of the officer of the watch who had deviated from the passage plan and passed the ship on the wrong side of Irbe Lighthouse.

Location: Warnemunde, beach area west of the west Mole
InitialEvent: Running aground and getting free with outside help
SummaryOfEvents: On May 2008, the yacht Intention IV, which is used and licensed for training purposes, left its mooring at the alten Strom in Warnemunde. On board were the Skipper and four participants, on a training voyage for the Coastal Skipper Certificate. Shortly after casting off, while close to the moles, the visibility rapidly worsened because of thick fog. The radar unit and the VHF marine radio on board the yacht were not used sufficiently, so that a near-collision resulted with an incoming ferry. Afterwards the yacht kept proceeding out to sea and there was a further near-collision with another yacht. Once at sea the visibility improved. After manoeuvre training, Intention IV was supposed to return to Warnemunde port. To do so the yacht had to re-enter the area of reduced visibility, where a close quarters situation occurred with another pleasure craft. Later the sails were taken down and the yacht proceeded under engine. In this part of the voyage too, the crew only used the technical equipment present in an inadequate manner. This led to the yacht running aground approximately 220 metres west of the West Mole.  The ship could only be freed with outside help. Nobody was injured and there was no damage to the ship.

InitialEvent: Hull failure / failure of watertight doors / ports, etc.
SummaryOfEvents: At 21.59 hours LT on 2nd May 2008 the dredger BRAGE R was testing some newly installed dredging equipment when the vessel experienced an ingress of water on her starboard side, forward and aft. The Master of the vessel decided to ground the vessel on a nearby sandbank and the testing was halted. When the ingress of water was stopped, the vessel was able to maneuvre into port under her own power. An examination and tests performed whilst alongside revealed that the water ingress was caused by a flange in the jetwater pipe system not being mounted.

On 2nd May 2008 the m/v SC BALTIC experienced a crankcase explosion at 18.30 hours LT during her outbound voyage from Bergen.
There were no injuries.

Location: Mississippi, Rich Bend, Buoy 156 near College Pt
SummaryOfEvents: On 2nd May 2008 the m/v EUPEN was on the Mississippi river. At around 15.00 hours LT she ran aground when changing course as a result of the strong currents.

On 2 May 2008, the Bluebridge passenger and freight ferry Monte Stello was transiting Tory Channel in Marlborough Sounds en route from Picton to Wellington when it suffered an electrical power failure, resulting in a loss of both propulsion engines. The emergency power system started automatically and supplied power to critical systems. The ship was brought up to its starboard anchor about 250 m from the shore line.
Power was restored and the ship proceeded back to Picton where the passengers and freight were put ashore to allow the ship to return empty to Wellington to investigate the cause of the power failure.
Two diesel generators were supplying power to the ship when first one, then the other, tripped off the power distribution bus-bars. Additionally the programmable logic controller (PLC) for the engine room alarm monitoring system developed an irreparable fault, but it could not be established if this was linked to the power failure or was a separate event. The cause of the diesel generators tripping off the bus could not be conclusively determined.
Safety issues discussed include: the difficulties in maintaining equipment on ships when information on maintenance and modifications to systems have not been passed on from previous owners; equipment and system drawings do not match the installation; and manufacturers of equipment and systems consider them obsolete and no longer support them.
A safety recommendation was made to the Director of Maritime New Zealand (Maritime NZ) that this report be sent to the International Maritime Organization (IMO), bringing to its attention the safety issue that there is no mandatory requirement for continuity of ships maintenance records and system diagrams when ships change ownership, and inviting it to refer this report on to the appropriate committee for its consideration.

Location: Canal de salida. Bocana  del puerto de Tarfaya
SummaryOfEvents:
El buque de Ro-Ro y Pasaje denominado ASSALAMA realizaba una línea regular con dos viajes semanales entre los puertos de Tarfaya (Marruecos) y el Puerto del Rosario (Isla de Fuerteventura, Islas Canarias- España).

El día 30 de Abril de 2008, en la maniobra de salida y justo en la bocana del puerto de Tarfaya el buque toco con su pantoque de babor los arrecifes que bordean el canal de salida produciéndole  vías de agua en la sala de maquinas, la  inundación no pudo ser controlada por los medios del buque y ante el peligro inminente el Capitán opto por fondear el buque a unos 200 mts de la playa en las cercanías de la bocana del puerto, en donde finalmente el buque debido a la inundación quedo varado sobre el fondo de arena.  Declarándose la pérdida total del buque 

                               No se produjeron daños personales, ni tampoco se ha reportado al momento del cierre de este informe de ningún daño al medio ambiente por vertidos  de hidrocarburos.

		       Todos los pasajeros fueron desembarcados y llevados a tierra desde el momento del fondeo y la tripulación abandonó el buque horas antes de su hundimiento  y  varada en el banco de arena. 

Posteriormente a mediados de Julio de 2008 la compañía de seguros se hizo cargo del buque, extrajo  todos los combustibles y productos oleosos del buque iniciando los preparativos para reflotarlo y remolcarlo al puerto de  Estambul en Turquía para su desguace

AT 15.40 HOURS LT ON 29 APRIL 2008 THE GENERAL CARGO SHIP 'BURAK KALKAVAN' WAS IN THE BOSPHORUS STRAIT WHEN SHE EXPERIENCED ENGINE FAILURE. FROM HER POSITION NEAR BEYLERBEYI LIGHTHOUSE, SHE  BEGAN DRIFTING TOWARDS THE SHORE.

Location: 41 miles SE from the Sochungdo Light House,Koea
SummaryOfEvents: The 203 Manseong (36.00gt) carried fish from a fishery work site in the west coast and was headed for the port of Mohang, Taean, at a position of 110° and at a speed of 10.0 knots. The Asian star (4,811.00gt) had left from the port of Incheon, heading for Longkau, China, at a position of 283° and a speed of 13.8 knots. At 13:50 on 29 April 2008, the two vessels collided 41 miles off the Socheongdo light beacon in Ongjingun in the southeast direction as the visibility was reduced to 50~60m due to heavy fog. As a result of the accident, the 203 Manseong broke into 3 pieces and sank, and of its 3 crew members, 2 were missing and with 1 member being rescued by the Asianstar.

SC BALTIC was alongside in Ørsta, Norway. At around noon on 19 April the crew finished the discharging and loading and was making ready for departure. This included the closing of the side-doors. During this operation the ordinary seaman (OS) fell down from the elevator and was injured.

The OS was closing the no. 2 side-door, the aft one. He was alone on this part of the tween-deck. During the closing operation the OS was standing on the cargo elevator, which was in a hoisted position. He tried to lower the elevator by using the remote control box, but nothing happened.

Then suddenly the elevator fell down, because it slipped from a position where it, some way or another, had been in a tight corner and because the wires were slack due to the OS’s attempt to lower the elevator.
When the wires tightened up the elevator stopped abruptly about 2m above the tweendeck, and the OS was thrown off the elevator and down on the deck.

The bosun, who saw the OS falling down, at once called other crew members and the captain. An ambulance was called for, and it arrived very soon after the accident and took the OS to the local hospital.

The OS had broken his right arm, had damaged his left heel and had several minor wounds at his head.

Location: AT SEA FROM FREEPORT (BAHAMAS) TO MONTREAL (CANADA)
SummaryOfEvents:
AFTER THE MSC TRINIDAD HAD ARRIVED IN MONTREAL, CANADA ON APRIL 28TH 2008 (PROCEEDING FROM FREEPORT, BAHAMAS) THE CANADIAN AUTHORITIES RECEIVED ALLEGATIONS FROM CREW MEMBERS THAT THE VESSEL HAD ILLEGALLY DISCHARGED OILY MIXTURES IN CANADIAN WATERS. THE VESSEL WAS INSPECTED BY PORT STATE AUTHORITIES IN MONTREAL ON APRIL 29th, 2008. A TOTAL OF 42 RELATED SAFETY DEFICIENCIES WERE FOUND, INCLUDING WORKING DEFICIENCIES OF THE OIL WATER SEPARATOR. THE VESSEL WAS CONSEQUENTLY DETAINED.

DUE TO AN ON GOING JUDICIARY PROCESS AT THE TIME OF WRITING THIS REPORT, TRANSPORT CANADA WAS NOT IN A POSITION TO DISCLOSE INFORMATION  ABOUT WHETHER TRACES OF OIL WERE FOUND ALONG THE ROUTE OF THE SHIP, AND IF SO, THEIR LOCATION AND QUANTITY OF ANY OIL SPILLED. NONETHELESS, THERE WERE NO REPORTS IN THE PUBLIC DOMAIN OF VISIBLE OIL SPILLS IN THE AREA TRANSITED BY THE VESSEL DURING THE TIME OF THE ALLEGED ILLEGAL
On 28th April 2008 the general cargo ship AKEELA was at Doha Port.....

Location: At the entrance of the river of Penerf
SummaryOfEvents:
Le vendredi 25 avril 2008, le fileyeur polyvalent  La Mélodie des Mers  quitte le port du Tour du Parc vers 06:30 heure afin de relever  des filets  et des  casiers à seiche dans les secteurs de Penestin et de Piriac-sur-Mer.

A bord se trouve le patron, ses deux matelots ainsi que deux passagers. Un autre navire de pêche, le Lambada  travaille dans le même secteur et les deux patrons communiquent régulièrement  par VHF. Les conditions météorologiques sont bonnes.

La pêche  étant terminée, les deux navires font route vers le port en empruntant la passe Est de la rivière de Pénerf. Le Lambada précède La Mélodie des Mers. 

Arrivée à « La Traverse », La Mélodie des Mers naviguant au pilote automatique  et sans veille à la timonerie, heurte violemment le socle de l’une des deux balises  latérales bâbord de la passe, cassée lors de la tempête  du 10 mars 2008 et recouverte  par la marée montante. Le choc à lieu du côté bâbord, vraisemblablement au niveau de la flottaison ou de la quille anti-roulis.
Au moment de l’accident, le patron  nettoyait des blancs  de seiches en se tenant assis sur la lisse bâbord, à proximité de la double commande Le navire coule en quelques minutes et un matelot disparaît. L’épave sera localisée par 8 mètres de fond à la position 47°29.8 N  002°38.7 W
Malgré les recherches entreprises immédiatement, le corps du marin ne sera retrouvé que  trois semaines plus tard.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship rendered unfit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents: At about 1340 on 25th April, 2008, Germany registered container ship "HANSA INDIA" collided with container ship "GUAN HANG 372". "HANSA INDIA" was under pilotage. The incident caused minor damages to the container carried on "GUAN HANG 372". No obvious damage to "HANSA INDIA". According to marine investigation, the main reason of this incident was inappropriate seamanship. No casualties and pollution reported.

Por malas condiciones meteorológicas en la ruta oceánica, el carguero "FARUK KAAN", de 7.738 de registro, 115 metros de eslora, 8 metros de calado, cargado con 8.049 toneladas y con dos Prácticos de Canales embarcados, decidió ingresar a aguas interiores cruzando el Canal Pulluche de Sur a Norte.
La restricción para Canal Pulluche era de 7,5 metros de calado en bajamar, por lo que la nave excedía en 50 centímetros el resguardo que recomendaba el derrotero. 
No obstante ello, el Capitán estuvo de acuerdo en realizar la navegación, utilizando para ello el Paso Recto, que se abre entre Bajo Roepke y la Punta del Bajo, el cual aún cuando presenta menos agua, requiere de un número menor de maniobras de caída para su cruce, que el otro paso disponible. El Oficial de Guardia, si bien estaba en el puente junto al Capitán, no se involucraba activamente en tareas de control de la navegación.
Franqueado el Bajo Roepke, la nave, que sólo controlaba su derrota por medio del índice paralelo del radar y representaba su posición por GPS sobre una carta náutica desplegada en un computador portátil con un sistema de registrador de track “Ozi Explorer”, se desvió de la ruta trazada, pasando cerca de un bajo marcado en la carta con una sonda de 9.8 metros, en cuyas inmediaciones tenía un bajo desconocido de 6,4 metros, en el cual tocó fondo sin quedar aprisionada. 
La nave resultó con fisuras y abolladuras en el casco, sin causar contaminación al mar ni lesiones a la dotación. Los daños fueron reparados de fortuna, permitiéndosele continuar su navegación a dique.

0n 9th April 2008 the general cargo vessel JUMANA sailed from loading port Kandala en route to Jeddah. At 08.00 hours LT on 20th April 2008 the vessel was approaching Jeddah Port at a course of 025 (T) and speed of 8.7 Knots. when the third officer took over watch from the Chief Officer; the vessel was on auto pilot. At 09.58 hours LT she altered her course to 057 (T) or 45 (M) according to the passage plan. ( Contradictory to the GPS Log entry at 1000 hrs.)
The A/B then took over the wheel from third Officer, course maintained on 045 (M). The
third Officer checked the position of the vessel and found it on track. ( no document evidence exists. the ship might have already gone off track by that time).
At 10.15 hours LT the Master ordered change of course to 005 (M), which was different to the passage plan to pass vessel off the near by ships.
A steering order of port 10 was inapproppriately given the proximity to bouy 4. There is no evidence of the of the nearby ships based on the vhf log)
At 10.23 hours LT the third Officer & Chief plotted ship´s position and and found her 3nm off- track. The Master was informed.
At 1025 hours LT the vessel's position was checked again, and danger confirmed; Master ordered hard starboard. ( No engine room order given to minimize the impact of the inevitable grounding). At 14.25 hours LT divers conducted an underwater inspection.
A further underwater inspection was carried out on 24th April 2008.
On 29th April 2008 the ship´s heading changed from 029°to 340°, list changed from 6°(Port Side)  t0 10° (Port Side); Starboard side ballasting carried out to reduce the list caused by rough seas and strong wind.
On 30th April 2008 the ship was re-floated and the anchor dropped, emergency pumps requested to pump out water from hold 2. On 2nd May at 01.55 hours the ship berthed and started discharging cargo.
On 8th May 2008 an underwater CCTV survey was carried out at Jeddah Port berth to assess the damages. Ship later sent to the dry dock for repair.

At about 1950 on 19th April, 2008, Greece registered oil tanker "ASTRO LEON", blew away from the berth by suddenly strong gust, and resulted in grounding about 100m away from her berth. "ASTRO LEON" was in reconstruction in YouLian Shipyard. The incident caused minor damages to the tanker. According to marine investigation, the main reason of this incident was the sudden gust caused by the air current of hurricane "raccoon", and "ASTRO LEON" master’s lacking of due attention of the influence of "raccoon".

SOLASStatus: CONTI HARMONY: Unknown/unspecified, GOTLAND CAROLINA: SOLAS
SummaryOfEvents:
Gotland Carolina loaded 21.687 MT Jet A1 in Mina Abdullah on 13th and 19.861 MT Jet A1 in Shuaiba on 17th April for Avonmouth, UK.

The vessel left shuaiba at 1245 LMT on the 17th April and at 0925 LMT on the 19th April the Gotland Carolina collided with the MV Conti Harmony IMO 9137894 in position 
25º 25’.3 N,  057º 21’.7 E.

The Gotland Carolina was damaged on the aft starboard quarter and returned to Fujairah anchorage for repairs. No injuries or oil spill occurred 

Temporary repairs were completed on 23rd April and the vessel continued her voyage on  24th at 1815 LMT.

Location: Entrance of Yangzi River in China
SummaryOfEvents: At 22.05 hours LT on April 15th 2008, the MV SHANGHAI SUPER EXPRESS collided with the fishing boat LuChangYu 5166 at the entrance to the Yangzi river. The collision caused the fishing boat to capsize and its crew to fall into the water. Eventually three crew members were rescued, but ten others were missing and one was found dead.

Location: Entrance of Yangzi River in China
SummaryOfEvents: At 06.58 hours LT on April 11th 2008 the general cargo ship  HAN LORD collided with fishing boat M/V Zhe Daiyu 11524 in waters nearby31°01＇30″N/123°20＇09″E. As a result of the accident the fishing boat sank very quickly and all the seamen fell into the water. Only four of the fourteen crew members from the fishing boat were rescued.

On 10th April 2008 the bulk carrier OCEAN SYMPHONY was at western working anchorage in Singapore. At 21.20 hours LT CDT Mr. N. Joshi was carrying a parcel to the service boat when he lost his balance on the bottom platform of the gangway and fell into the water.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship rendered unfit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents: The tug "BARTA" and another two tugs were ordered to assist m/v "MAGDALENA" in mooring to the berth operations. The inbound m/v "MAGDALENA" was in ballast and underway in the port channell with pilot on board and kept a speed of approx. 6 knots. Three tugs met the vessel inside the port area and approached her to take and to give ropes according to scheme agreed with the pilot. The tug "BARTA" approached bow of the m/v "MAGDALENA" and was proceeding in parallel to the vessel's stem line while tug's 2 crew members on deck reached by boat-hook a towing rope lowered from central lead of the "MAGDALENA" and put it on the towing hook. When the rope was in place, the s/s of the tug "BARTA" and the bulbous bow of the m/v "MAGDALENA" got in contact. Then immediately the tug was turned with right angles to the bulbous bow and listed to the p/s. "MAGDALENA" with the bulb was pushing ahead the tug and the the tug started to take a water on main deck. Finaly the tug capsized. Two crew members of the tug "BARTA" died. One rescued. Capsized tug was towed to the shallow water and lifted  by floating cranesa after few days.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship rendered unfit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents:
AT 07:30 HOURS ON APRIL 10th, 2008 THE WIPER ON BOARD THE VEHICLES CARRIER "SEA VENUS" WAS LEAVING THE ENGINE ROOM WHEN HE NOTICED THAT FIRE WAS COMING OUT OF THE TURBO CHARGER . HE IMMEDIATELY SHOUTED "FIRE", AND THE FIRST ENGINEER RAISED THE SHIP ALARM AND ATTEMPTED TO FIGHT THE FIRE WITH PORTABLE EXTINGUISHERS, BUT THE FLAMES WERE TOO FIERCE.   
THE MAIN ENGINE AND THE AUXILIARY BLOWER, FUEL PUMP AND ENGINE ROOM FAN MOTOR WERE ALL STOPPED. 
THE CREW ATTEMPTED TO EXTINQUISH THE FIRE USING EXTUINGUISHERS BUT THE FIRE CONTINUED TO SPREAD.  
 EPIRB WAS ACTIVATED AND THE CANADIAN NAVY CARRIED OUT SEARCH AND RESCUE OPERATION ALONG WITH TWO MERCHANT SHIPS. THE VESSEL SUSTAINED MAJOR DAMAGE AND SOME CREW MEMBERS RECEIVED SERIOUS BURNS.
M/V SEA VENUS WAS TOWED SAFELY BACK TO HALIFAX.

Location: 57 miles off from the lighthouse of the island of Yierdo
SummaryOfEvents: The Korean-registered general cargo vessel Pan Bless was built and launched at Mitsubishi Heavy Industry in Japan in January 1994, and was owned and used by Bumyoung Shipping Co., Ltd. She was 16,446 G/T, 158.60m in length, 27.00m in width, 13.30m in depth, and powered by one 5,368kw diesel engine. The ship left the port of Nahodka in Russia at around 19:50 on April 4th, 2008, and headed for the port of Hipon in Vietnam, carrying about 25,923 tons of iron material. There were a total of 22 crew members including Captain and Third Officer , who were involved in the accident. At around 08:45 on 7th April, Captain was navigating under restricted visibility conditions due to heavy fog at a course of about 219° and at a speed of around 12knots about 57 miles off the lighthouse of the island of Yierdo on position 31°30’00’’N-126°03’59’’E, when the ship's bow collided with the starboard area of the wheel house of a Chinese wooden fishing boat named Lujiayu0597, which was anchored after her fishing works. She was 49.00 G/T, 19.5m in length, 4.92m in width, 1.79m in depth, and powered by one diesel engine. As a result of the accident, the Pan Bless sustained little damage, while the Lujiayu0597 sank and 6 out of its 8 crew members were reported missing.

While the "Black Watch" was berthed port side alongside the conveyor pier at Safaga, Egypt on 5th April 2008, the Master had scheduled a Crew Emergency Boat Drill to take place. On this occasion it was planned to lower the starboard side lifeboats as part of the Emergency Drill.

During launch of enclosed lifeboat #7 (Stbd Side) from it's stowed position, the Coxswain was in charge at the launching/release platform at Deck No. 8 position together with the person in charge of the release brake, who was standing on the winch platform.

At about 10:30hrs, when the lashing wires at the forward and aft of boat were released, the person on the winch started to release the brake and let go to launch the boat to the embarkation deck at deck 7. At this time there was nobody inside the boat, but when the boat was approaching the ship's bulwark at the embarkation deck, the forward on-load release hook came off the lifting block end and the lifeboat bow suddenly came crushing down along the starboard shipside. As the bow was released, the weight of the boat suddenly pulled down part of the track way, also damaging the ship's bulwark.
The Lifeboat remained hanging vertically, bow pointing down from the severed damaged aft davit, but sustained severe damage.

There were no persons injured as a result of this incident.

The vessel's shipside suffered no damage except for minor dents and several scratches along the sliding path.  

The davit and the lifeboat were severely damaged.

Location: 125 miles off from the lighthouse of the island of Yierdo
SummaryOfEvents: The Captain of the general cargo vessel Bright Ace (6,049.0 G/T) was alone on navigational watch at around 08:05 on 5 April 2008 under poor visibility conditions. He was not concentrating on the radar lookout and failed to detect early a trawler, Zhepuyu 34368. As a result, Bright Ace collided with Zhepuyu 34368 at around 08:40 at 198° and 125 miles from the Ieo island lighthouse. On the other hand, trawler Zhepuyu 34368 (86 G/T) was fishing when it collided with the other vessel due to radar lookout negligence. As a result of the accident, Zhepuyu 34368 sank and its 5 crew members went missing.

Location: Offshore from the Kugurizaka Fishing Port, Aomori City, Aomori Prefecture
SummaryOfEvents: The fishing vessel Nikko-maru set sail from the Kugurizaka Fishing Port, Aomori City, Aomori Prefecture at approximately 02:00 hours on April 5, 2008, with seven persons aboard in addition to the captain,.for the purpose of harvesting a scallop farm, and, having harvested the farmed scallops at the scallop farming facilities off the shore of the same fishing port in Mutsu Bay, was returning to port when it sunk at approximately 03:44 hours killing all eight persons on board.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
On 4 April 2008 at 20 :26 hours (UTC + 2 hours), the forward tug Wilhelmine, broached to in front of the bow to the Russian ship Pavel Korchagin bound for upcoming the Sudwesthafen Mort. The accident occurred in the Port of Hamburg., off Tollerort, as the tripping line of the hawser was being hauled up. Endeavours had yet been made to move clear by applying “full ahead” and counter steering. The tug was, however, listing to starboard and the deck had been flooded. Then the tug came clear, righted itself and ended up on the port side of the seagoing ship. On the bridge, two people were knocked to the floor. At the stern of the ship, one person fell outboard board but was able to hold on to a tire fender.
The wind came from SW at a force of 2 Bft and visibility was 4 km
Consequences1: Serious injuries,Ship rendered unfit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents:
