1. On the 4 April 2008, the general cargo ship CIMBRIS was alongside in the port of Tekirdag, Turkey undertaking cargo discharging operations. The hatch cover gantry crane was being used to move the hatchcovers under the supervision of the Chief Officer. Following a reported problem with cargo acceptance this operation was halted whilst the Chief Officer went to consult with the stevedores and the ships agent regarding the cargo stoppage.

2. The hatch cover lifting operation was then restarted after approximately ten minutes in the absence of the Chief Officer with the AB (senior) standing on the tween deck hatch cover that was being moved, the hatch cover was hoisted approximately one metre and then halted as the cover was visually checked for clearence, upon recommencing the lift the hoist wires and the lifting frame fell onto the AB causing fatal injuries.

3. Upon being alerted the Master requested an ambulance and proceeded to the cargo hold where a number of crewmembers had mustered to assist, paramedics arrived on the vessel within ten minutes of the accident with it being apparent that the AB had died as a result of the accident. The body of the deceased was moved ashore to a mortuary later that evening.

4. The vessel was subsequently diverted to Gibraltar and was attended on the 14 April 2008 for the purposes of undertaking an enquiry into the death of the seaman under Section 92 of the Gibraltar Merchant Shipping (Accident Reporting and Investigation) Regulations 2006 was also commenced.

On 2nd April 2008 at 01.03 hours LT  the Liberia flagged M/V "MSC CHARLESTON"  and Chinese flagged M/V "KAI FENG 16" collided at precautionary area"A" of ChangJiangKou area. The midship of "KAI FENG 16"was damaged severely and the  bulb bow of "MSC CHARLESTON" was damaged slightly.

At 06:01 hours on 1 June 2008, the container ship Marfeeder, sailing under German flag, collided with the container ship APL Turquoise, sailing under Singapore flag, in visibility of less than 1000 m in the fairway of the Weser. The scene of the accident is situated approximately 1000 m south-east of the river bend at the Robbennordstreert Light. Both ships had a pilot and were also assisted by radar pilot from Vessel Traffic Service (VTS) Bremerhaven. After the collision, the Marfeeder sailed on to the Stromkage at Bremerhaven and the APL Turquoise anchored at the anchorage, Neue Weser N-Reede. The accident did not lead to any injuries. The Marfeeder was severely damaged on the port side and lost her rescued boat during the collision. The APL Turquoise had a crack on the port forecastle above the water line and was able to continue her voyage on the following night. No pollutants escaped

Le 31 Mars 2008 à 23:55 heures, le navire fluvio-maritime Natissa, battant pavillon maltais et transportant 1470  tonnes de ciment de Nice à Lyon, s’est échoué sur l’îlot du Gros Sarrandier situé au Sud-Est de l’île de Porquerolles. 

Il n’y a eu ni victime ni pollution, seuls les fonds du peak avant, du local propulseur et du premier  ballast situé derrière ont été endommagés.

Le navire a pu être déséchoué  dès le mercredi 2  Avril et gagner, accompagné d’un remorqueur, mais par ses propres moyens, le port de Toulon.

Location: At sea, southeast of Esperance Western Australia
SummaryOfEvents:
At 10.15 hours LT on 31st March 2008, a fire started in the engine room of the container ship MSC LUGANO. The chief engineer operated the quick closing valves and the remote stops for the engine room fans and fuel pumps. The crew closed the dampers for the engine room fans and the funnel vents and rigged fire hoses to boundary to cool the engine room casing and the funnel. 

After about 50 minutes, the fire cut the electrical power supply to the emergency fire pump and water ceased to flow from the fire hoses. The master ordered the crew to close the engine room skylight and then muster. He then instructed the chief engineer to activate the ship’s fixed fire extinguishing system.

At 11.20 hours LT, the master reported the fire to the Australian Rescue Coordination Centre (RCC).

By 15.00 hours LT, the crew had determined that the fire was extinguished. The engine room was ventilated and the crew entered to assess the damage. They were able to re-start many of the engine room systems and restore electrical power but they could not re-start the main engine. The ship was by then about 90 miles south of Esperance, Western Australia and drifting towards the Archipelago of the Recherche.

The ship’s managers entered into an agreement to tow the ship to Fremantle and, on 1 April, the tug Wambiri departed from Fremantle, Western Australia. Three other tugs, two based in Esperance and one that was in the vicinity towing a barge, were tasked to assist the ship until Wambiri arrived. 

By 12.45 hours LT on 5 April, Wambiri had rendezvoused with MSC LUGANO and taken the ship in tow. At 15.06 hours LT on 13 April 2008 the disabled ship berthed in Fremantle.

Late March 2008, during a voyage from the river Hollands, Diep (Rhine estuary) to South Italy, the river – sea ship Advance is on passage through Jobourg then Ushant Tss, despite adverse weather conditions.  
On Sunday morning 30 March, ingress of sea water, that was not possible to pump; is detected in the fore compartments, ahead of the collision bulkhead. After a rerouting attempt towards Brest then to La Rochelle, because of the worsening situation, the crew abandon ship and is rescued by the French frigate Tourville helicopter.
Advance sank two on 31 March 2008, 77 miles South-South-West.

ON MARCH 27TH, 2008 THE M/V ZEIN I, WITH IMO NO: 7622041, WAS INVOLVED IN FIRE AND EXPLOSION AT THE ALEXANDRIA SHIPYARD, RESULTING IN THE DEATH OF FOUR LABOURERS AND TWENTY-THREE INJURIES ON BOARD.
THE APPARENT CAUSE OF THE FIRE WAS A SUDDEN SPARK DURING WELDING REPAIRS BEING ONDER TAKEN AT THE ALEXANDRIA SHIPYARD.

On 24th March 2008 the LAUWERSBORG was approaching the port of Hundested when visibilitybecame drastically reduced. This resulted in the vessel unexpectedly touching bottom, although chart did not indicate reduced depth.

The vessel was engaged in a seismic survey off the NW coast of Australia, on the morning of 24 March 2008. As per the company internal procedures the lifeboats are swung out every two weeks. The CO with his crew decided to swing both the lifeboats on that day. The Port LB was swung out without incident and subsequently housed. The stb LB was swung and as the "deployment arresters" were fully extended, the aft chain (attachments from the falls to the lifeboat hook) parted. This resulted in a shift of direction of the the working forces on the forward fall, causing the davit to collapse and forward fall wire to part. The lifeboat fell into the water and was dragged alongside the vessel for approx. 15mins after which time the boats painter line parted.

The damaged vessel was recovered and towed into port by the vessel's chase boat. No personal injuries were caused during this incident.

SOLASStatus: LANCE NAIK ALBERT EKKA PVC: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: At approximately 16.15 hours on 21st March 2008 the m/v LANCE NAIK ALBERT EKKA PVC made contact with jetty No. 1 whilst approaching the oil terminal in the port of Kandla. There was one tug in assistance on the starboard side. During the operation, the vessel experienced off shore winds of about 8kts (on port quarter), and the tide was slack. The pilot had estimate a tide of 2.5 kts to change to ebb by the time the vessel approached the berth. The Pilot tried to align the vessel to the jetty using transverse through at full astern propulsion. While doing so, the bulbous bow of the tanker made contat with jetty no. 1. There was no loss of life, no oil pollution and only shell plates of the tanker sustained damage.

At about 2113 local time on 22 March 2008, the China registered bulk carrier Yao Hai collided with the Ukraine registered supply tug Neftegaz-67 in Hong Kong, China waters in position 22-20.7'N  114-00.1'E. At the time of the accident, the weather condition was cloudy with light rain. There was a westerly light breeze and a smooth sea with a moderate visibility of about 2 nautical miles (n.m.). Yao Hai sustained damages to the stem and bulbous bow while Neftegaz-67 sustained damages to the starboard side shell and starboard shaft tunnel. Neftegaz-67 listed to starboard and sank shortly after the collision. Six crew members and an interpreter of Neftegaz-67 were rescued and the remaining eighteen crew members were drowned inside the vessel.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
ON 22 MARCH 2008 THE CONTAINER SHIP "CS SIGNE" WAS HEADING UP THE HOOGLY RIVER TO CALCUTTA PORT, WITH PILOT ON BOARD,  WHEN SHE RAN AGROUND ON SOFT MUD.  THERE WAS NO DAMAGE TO THE VESSEL' S MACHINERY / STEERING / MANNING / FUEL / BRIDGE / EQUIPMENTS / ETC.  AFTER 11 HOURS AND THE NEXT HIGH TIDE SHE WAS AFLOAT  AND PROCEEDED TO HER DESTINATION PORT CALCUTTA UNDER HER OWN POWER.
WHILE GROUNDING ON THE WAY VESSEL'S BOW HAD DAMAGED FINGER JETTY WALKWAY.

On the evening of 21st March 2008 a pilot was supposed to come onboard the tug Karl-Erik, pushing a barge. Due to heavy seas and strong wind the decision was made that the boarding should take place closer to the port. The bulwark on the tugboat was leaning inwards, so when the pilot tried to go onboard, without a pilot ladder, she stepped on the outside of the bulwark with her left leg. Because of the waves the pilot boat lifted, and the rubber fender hit the pilot's left leg.
Consequences1: Serious injuries,Ship remains fit to proceed

Location: Off Yanai city, Yamaguchi Prefecture, Japan
SummaryOfEvents: On 21st March 2008 the chemical tanker ACE TRANSIA (registered Panama, 739gt, built 1991), was en route from Otake, Japan to Ulsan, Korea. At approximately 18.50 hours LT she struck a bridge column of the Oshima Bridge, off Yanai city, Yamaguchi Prefecture, Japan, causing water ingress into its ballast tanks. There was no oil spill and no injuries were reported.

Le lundi 19 Mars 2007, a 01 :14 heures, le CROSS Etel reçoit une alerte de détresse du FMCC sans position résolue en provenance du navire Rose des Vents. Il s’agit d’un chalutier du Croisic de 11 mètres.

Après confirmation que le chalutier est en mer avec deux personnes à bord et réception d’une position résolue au large de Saint-Nazaire, le CROSS-A met d’importants moyens maritimes et aériens en œuvres. Les conditions météorologiques sont mauvaises, avec coup de vent de Nord-Ouest et met forte.

Dans la journée, les moyens sur zone signalent la présence de divers objets ou débris pouvant appartenir au Rose Des vents.

Les corps des deux marins seront retrouvés le mos suivant. 

Les importants moyens mis en œuvres par la Marine nationale pour localiser l’épave s’avéreront infructueux.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: 2008-march-17th-1159HRS LT，the container M/V COSCO AMERICA navigated  in the fog condition from NINGBO to XIAMEN collided with the M/V XIANGWANGCAI16 at NINGBO ZHITOU and caused some damages to both vessels.

On 17th March 2008 the bulk carrier PANAMAX PEPPOU was at outer anchorage at Qingado, China,
where a report detailing notification of the death of the ship's Master was submitted to the authorities.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents: At 20.30 hours LT on 16th March 2008 the chemical tanker ANGLO was off Rorvik when she experienced an engine breakdown, making the ship unfit to proceed.

On 16th March 2008 the roro cargo ferry MERCANDIA VIII was approaching Elsinore in dense fog when she hit the breakwater at 07.50 hours LT, and damaged her bowdoors. The main contributory cause was a reversion of the current just outside the harbour entrance. This confused the autopilot, which lead to a port turn. Due to the fog this port turn was discovered too late. Crew tried to perform a starboard turn in order to clear the breakwater, but due to the proximity to the breakwater this was unsuccessful.

On 16th March 2008 the dredger SIF R ran aground with a full cargo of dredging material. This was caused by poor navigation while going outbound, resulting in severe leakage in forecastle and generator room.

Location: Porto de Aratu - liquid products Terminal, Bahia, Brazil
SummaryOfEvents:
On 15th  March 2008 at 15.30 hours LT, the Norwegian flag tanker ship for Chemicals & Oil Products NCC Jubail, Call sign LAYZ4, 23196 gt, built 1996, IMO Nr 9087025, Length o.a. 183.10 meters, with 29 crew, owned by National Chemical Carriers Ltd. Co. and operated commercially and managed by Odfjell SE was involved in a collision with Porto de Aratu's wharf, Lat. 12º 46,980'S e Long. 038º 30,038'W. The collision took place during the unmooring manoeuvre from the gaseous and liquid products Terminal, and caused a rupture three meters in diameter in the hull at starboard side, 2 meters above the waterline. 
The rupture resulted in a five cubic meter spill of oil lubricant into the sea. The emergency plan of Aratu Port was activated by the Harbors Captaincy of  Bahia to tackle the hydric pollution, by means of containment and oil absorption blankets/ barriers.
No personel injuries were observed, but the ship sustained damages in the propulsion system and was unfit to proceed on her trip.

Location: Cuxhaven, on the river Elbe of Amerikahafen
SummaryOfEvents: On 14 March 2008 Oceanic was to leave the Amerikahafen in Cuxhaven in order to move to Bremerhaven for repair of damages caused by collision. The pilot advice began after casting off. The ship Josef Möbius was dredging close to the entrance to Amerikahafen. She was proceeding up the river Elbe at a speed of 0.8 kts over ground. When Oceanic passed the entrance in the direction of the Elbe, the ship was caught by the ebb current. The tug did not succeed in manoeuvring past Josef Möbius in the space available so that the two ships made contact. The port side aft ship of the tug collided with the bow of the dredger. This did not cause any personal injuries.

On 14th March 2008 the Sea Venus experienced mechanical difficulty in firing the boiler at approximately 19.45 hours  LT. This occurred after the anchorage when the First Engineer and Oiler manually tried to reset and open the boiler by using a piece of cloth soaked with gas oil. As a result the boiler flared back and the Oiler,  sustained  2nd degree burns to the upper part of his body, particulary his neck, face and the frontal region of the head.

On 14 March 2008 at approximately 08:45 hours, the FV left Bunagee Pier, Culdaff, Co. Donegal to lift strings of pots. Crewmembers were on board.

The weather forecast was not for south to southwest Force 3 or 4 with good visibility and slight to moderate sea state. The reported weather conditions on the day were better than the forecast. 

At 17:17 hours, on 14 March 2008, a “999” call was made as the Strath Marie was overdue. At 18:13 hours, on 14 March 2008, the first casualty was recovered from the water and at 20:38 hours, the second casualty was recovered. 

Both men were brought to Altnagel vin Hospitla in Derry where they were later pronounced dead.

Parts of the fishing ship were later recovered and examined along with other evidence to try and establish the cause of the loss of the FV Strath Marie

No direct cause for the loss of both lives has been established.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
At 10:20, about 10 nm west of the Elbe Buoy, the engine of Hope Bay  failed. At this time there was a north-westerly wind of force 6 Bft. There was a storm warning for winds of strength 8 Bft in gusts of up to 10Bft that were reached in the course of the evening and the night. Hope Bay drifted in an easterly direction, initially without anchor and subsequently at anchor. The multipurpose ship Mellum was in the vicinity of the disabled ship as of 11:50 hours. At about VTS Wilhelmshaven dispatched the ocean tug Oceanic to Hope Bay at standby tug

When the main engine was running again at 19:00 hours, Hope Bay intended to follow the ship operator's instruction and sail to Cuxhaven. For this the ship was guided by a radar pilot from Elbe Approach East Radar to the estuary of the river Elbe. The ship passed the Elbe buoy at 20:31 hours. Fourteen minutes later the engine failed again. A tow connection was thereupon to be established by Oceanic. As a result of the sea state during the subsequent manoeuvres, several persons on board the tug were injured. There was slight contact between the two ships, the heaving line parted during handing-over of the towing gear, and at 22:49 hours the disabled ship and the tug collided. The severity of the damage led to discontinuation of the assignment and to the tug proceeding to Cuxhaven.
Further drifting of Hope Bay was prevented by means of dropping two anchors. In the afternoon of 13 March 2008 Bugsier 3 was able to establish a line connection and take Hope Bay to Cuxhaven

InitialEvent: Engine failure and collision with buoy
SummaryOfEvents: The refrigerated cargo ship Hope Bay, sailing under the flag of Netherlands Antilles, left the port of Hamburg with a pilot on board in the morning of 12 March 2008. As she was sailing down the river Elbe, the engine failed in the vicinity of buoy 90, necessitating emergency anchoring. Twenty minutes later the engine was operational again. The ship command attributed the engine failure to a defect in the automatic control. While weighing the anchor, there was contact with and warping of buoy 90. The ship then continued its voyage.
ON 10TH MARCH 2008 THE CONTAINER SHIP MSC SABRINA RAN AGROUND IN QUEBEC AT APPROXIMATELY 22.25 HOURS LT.

Alors qu'il faisait route par très mauvais temps, de conserve avec deux autres navires du même armement, afin de regagner son port d'attache de Saint-Quay-Portrieux, le Marie-Louise-Berthe est couché par une énorme lame qui brise les vitres de la passerelle.
 
Les cinq hommes d'équipage, qui n'ont pas eu le temps de mettre en œuvre les radeaux de sauvetage, sont précipités à la mer; ils sont tous recueillis sains et saufs quelques instants plus tard, en état d'hypothermie, par les deux autres chalutiers, aux prix de difficiles manœuvres.

La Mare-Louise-Berthe sombre définitivement peu après l'accident.
Consequences1: Serious injuries,Total loss of the ship

Location: Princessa Shoal, east of the Isle of Wight
SummaryOfEvents: On 10 March 2008, the Swedish registered tanker Astral dragged her anchor in severe weather and grounded on the Princessa Shoal, east of the Isle of Wight. Astral sustained indentations to her hull and extensive damage to her rudder and steering gear, there was no pollution and the ship remained watertight

Le lundi 10 Mars 2008, à 06: 45 heure locale, le  navire de commerce Artemis  battant pavillon des Pays-Bas se présente dans le chenal d’accès au port  des Sables d’Olonne en vue d’embarquer  le pilote. L’embarquement de celui-ci s’effectue à 07:05  à l’intersection des aliments des passes Sud-Ouest et Sud-Est. Les conditions météo sont mauvaises : vent de Sud-Ouest  force 7 avec rafales force 10 et  mer très forte.

Ce jour là, deux navires de commerces de tailles similaires sont attendus  pour la marée  06:09 : le MV Riga , chargé de 3530 tonnes de ciment, et le MV Artemis sur lest.

Dès son arrivée à la passerelle, le pilote juge  critique  la position  du navire par rapport  à  la côte  et la proximité  d’une bande  rocheuse, voire potentiellement dangereuse. Aussitôt, il tente avec le propulseur d’étrave, de faire remonter l’arrière du navire dans le vent.
Malgré cette manœuvre d’urgence, le navire  continue de dériver  à  faible  vitesse  au Nord-Ouest, et suite à un grain violent, vient s’échouer à 07:20 sur les sables d’Olonne, cap au  100, à la position 04629.60 N et 00116.95 W.

Il n’y a pas eu de blessés parmi les membres de l’équipage ne de pollution.

Après deux tentatives de remise à flot, le navire sera finalement  déséchoué le 20 Mars 2008

During heavy weather, the ship ARTEMIS approached the port of Les Sables d'Olonne. There is only one navigator on the bridge. The pilot cannot board at the pilot-station and the ship continues to enter the port to pick up the pilot between the breakwaters. Due to the wind and the current, the ship runs aground on the beach during high tide.  The ship remains buoyed until 20 March 2008.

On March 7th 2008, the container vessel MSC ROMA was transiting the Gulf of Aden from Singapore, bound for Valencia, when a fire broke out in the vessel's cargo hold at approximately 12.47 hours LT. The fire was extinguished with the vessel's CO2 bottles and water sprinkler system. Inspections after he fire revealed that the source was probably a contianer holding class 9 dangerous goods, specifically lithium batteries. Although much of the vessel's cargo was significantly damaged, there were no injuries reported. Flag state investigatin was conducgte by obtaining the flag state report and follow-up communications for clarifications after review as necessary.

ShipsInvolved: ANICHKOV BRIDGE (IMO 9256901), TOR CORONA (IMO 9357597), VALLE DI NERVION (IMO 9288942)
SOLASStatus: ANICHKOV BRIDGE: Unknown/unspecified, TOR CORONA: SOLAS, VALLE DI NERVION: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents:
On 6th March 2008 the m/v „TOR CORONA“ was in the channel of port Klaipeda, and reduced her speed to approximately 7 knots to allow the pilot to disembark inside the port area. The ro-ro vessel then headed out to sea, but began to drift northwards towards some berthed oil tankers under the impact of 15 m/s W wind and strong currents. The Master was unable to control the vessel and failed to switch on the bow thruster, which was switched off after the vessel left the berth. Continuing to drift at a speed of about 6 knots, the vessel's starboard side made contact with the oil tanker „ANICHKOV BRIDGE“, after which her her bulbous bow struck against the stern and ropes of another oil tanker the „VALLE DI NERVION“.
After the contact with tankers the ro-ro ship turned around and the pilot embarked the vessel again. She proceeded back to the port and berthed at the same berth. 
The ro-ro ferry „TOR CORONA“ sustained damage to her bulbous bow and side shell plating.  The m/v „VALLE DI NERVION“ was damaged to the stern and the m/v „ANICHKOV BRIDGE“ received damage to her port side. 
The M/v „TOR CORONA“ and m/v „VALLE DI NERVION“ were unable to continue their voyages. 
Nobody was injured during the accident, and the environment was not polluted.

On 6th March 2008 the m/v ERISO was Approaching a jetty when the skipper moved the bridge control lever to apply astern power. The CPP failed to operate and the vessel hit the jetty at approximately 3 knots.

ShipsInvolved: EISEI MARU No. 5 (IMO 8801577), GOLD LEADER (IMO 8014497), OCEAN PHENIX (IMO 9020704)
SOLASStatus: EISEI MARU No. 5: Unknown/unspecified, GOLD LEADER: SOLAS, OCEAN PHENIX: SOLAS
Location: In the Akashi Kaikyo Straight, Hyogo Prefecture, Japan
SummaryOfEvents:
General Cargo Ship Gold Leader (registered Belize, 1466gt, built 1980), with 9 crew members, Liquid Petroleum Gas Carrier Ocean Phoenix (registered Japan, 2948gt, built 1992) and dredger Eisei Maru No.5 (registered Japan, 496gt, built 1987) with 5 crew members were in collision in the Akashi Kaikyo Straight, Hyogo Prefecture, Japan.
Gold Leader sank, leaving 3 crew died and 1 crew missing, spilling fuel oil.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Pollution,Total loss of the ship

ShipsInvolved: CSCL Hamburg (IMO 9224300), CSCL HAMBURG (IMO 9224300), LIAN HUA FENG (IMO 9230361)
SOLASStatus: CSCL Hamburg: SOLAS, CSCL HAMBURG: SOLAS, LIAN HUA FENG: SOLAS
SummaryOfEvents: A collision accident occurred at about  2101 hours local time (Beijing time) , the 5th MAR 2008, between a Hong Kong, China Container  vessel “CSCL HAMBURG” proceeding from Hong Kong, China to Shanghai China and a China  Bulk  vessel “LIAN HUA FENG”. The accident caused both vessels partially destroyed but all the crew were safe.

On 3rd March 2008 the crew of the fishing vessel HANNY offloaded their fishing gear into the North sea for the first time on their trip. While putting the fishing gear into the water one crew member was hit by a steel cable. The injured crew member was evacuated by helicopter, but later died.

ON 3RD MARCH 2008 THE M/V 'ALIOTH LEADER' WAS ON THE WEST COAST  OF THE NETHERLANDS WHEN HER MAIN ENGINE NO 5 UNIT PISTON CROWN CRACKED.  THE VESSEL STOPPED ENGINES AND ANCHORED, AND THE PISTON CROWN WAS REPLACED WITH A SPARE OVERHAULED PIECE.
DUE TO ADVERSE WEATHER CONDITIONS THE VESSEL REQUESTED TUG ASSISTANCE  IN ORDER TO MAINTAIN ANCHOR POSITION DURING THE REPAIR PERIOD.  AFTER COMPLETION OF REPAIRS, VESSEL TESTED ENGINES FOR SATISFACTORY OPERATIONS AND THEN RESUMED VOYAGE.

Le mercredi 27 Février 2008 est un jour de pêche à la coquille Saint-Jacques en baie de Saint-Brieuc. Dans le but de préserver la ressource, cette activité est très réglementée. Elle se pratique deux à trois jours par semaine, du mois d'Octobre au mois d'Avril. Les jours où la pêche est autorisée, la coquille est draguée aux heures définies, pendant seulement 45 minutes, par plus de cents coquilliers qui opèrent sous étroite surveillance maritime et aérienne.

Le Pourquoi Pas a commencé sa journée en relevant une dizaine de filière de cassiers à boulots, avant de se rendre sur les lieux  où la coquille est graduée, le Trugarez quant à lui est sorti uniquement pour la marée de coquille.

L'abordage entre les deux navires survient quelques minutes après la fin de la période de pêche, au moment où  la flottille se disperse pour rejoindre les différents ports de la baie où les captures son commercialisées. 

La brèche due à l'abordage étant importante, le Trugarez coule rapidement. Son équipage, indemne, embarque à bord du Pourquoi Pas.
On 27th February 2008 the car carrier GRANDE NAPOLI ran aground in Doha territorial waters, Qatar.

On the evening of 25 February 2008 the product carrier, Sichem Melbourne, sustained damage and damaged mooring structures as she departed her berth at Coryton Oil Refinery on the River Thames estuary. Fortunately her broadside contact with a mooring dolphin prevented Sichem Melbourne from striking an oil tanker which was discharging on a neighbouring jetty.
Due to missing alteration of course at a waypoint, the ship continued on a course that lead to the grounding at the coast of Bornholm close to Roenne Harbour.

At about 22.40 hours on 23rd February, 2008, Panama registered container ship "RIVER ELEGANCE" collided with SCT 7# berths at ShenZhen port.  The "RIVER ELEGANCE" was under pilotage. The incident caused minor damage to the wharf. According to marine investigations, the main reason for this incident was the master and pilot’s inappropriate seamanship and lack of evaluation of the current. No casualties or pollution were reported.

At about 18.17 hours LT on 23 February 2008, the Marshall Islands registered passenger ship VAN GOGH grounded briefly on the western shore of the Mersey River during a departure from Devonport, Tasmania. The ship was under the conduct of a harbour pilot who had taken over the conduct from the master about five minutes before, after the master had manoeuvred the ship off the berth.

As the ship left the berth, it began to be set towards the bulk carrier Goliath berthed ahead. VAN GOGH  was under the influence of the ebb tide and fresh water that was flowing from the Mersey River’s catchment following heavy rain in the area in the previous 24 hours.

VAN GOGH was difficult to manoeuvre at low speed because of its twin propellers and single rudder configuration. This, combined with the strong ebb tide and fresh water outflow in the river at the time of departure, resulted in there being insufficient water flow over its rudder to enable the pilot to manoeuvre the ship as he intended. In addition, the master did not inform the pilot that the crew would be using the ship’s engines independently during turns in the river. This resulted in the pilot being concerned that his orders were being countermanded because he saw that the engine telegraph levers were not as he had ordered.

Following the grounding, the pilot successfully manoeuvred the ship back into the channel and the ship departed the port without further incident. There was no damage to the ship and no pollution resulted.

At about 07:30 on February 22nd 2008, the Liberian Bulk Carrier SELINDA was involved in a collision with the Chinese Flag vessel Hui Feng 98. While the SELINDA was transiting the Yangtze river under limited visibility conditions she noticed two smaller vessels, and to avoid colliding with either of them the SELINDA steered towards port. Having cleared one small vessel the other vessel - the Hui Feng 98 - made a sudden turn towards SELINDA, resulting in a collision. As a result, the Hui Feng 98 sank, and one of her crew members sustained serious injuries. In addition, the SELINDA required permanent hull repairs as well as a replacement anchor. Flag State investigation was conducted by obtaining the flag state report and follow-up communications for clarification after review as necessary.
Consequences1: Serious injuries,Ship rendered unfit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents:
On 20th February 2008 the general cargo vessel MATUA was entering Port Moroni when she hit an unmarked submerged "spar". The ship had a pilot on board, who did not inform crew about the underwater obstruction.

The ship received severe damage to the propellers, the propeller shaft and gear. Due to the damage of the propeller shaft, water ingressed into the engine room.

SOLASStatus: SILVER SPIRIT: SOLAS, SINAN ATASOY: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: At 03.15 hours LT on 19th February 2008 the general cargo ship SILVER SPIRIT, IMO NR. 8214798, was anchored at Iskenderun Bay (Anchor position 36040.6 N,  Long 0369-10.1 E)  awaiting to discharge about 3.400MT of light scrap from Casablance, Morocco. Due to a sudden change of weather conditions with gusty S. Westerly wind force 7 on Beaufort scale, and rough seas, the anchor was dragging and as a result the vessel came into very slight contact from its port bow with the starboard bow of M/V SINAN ATASOY, Turkish Flag.  No injuries were sustained, and nobody went missing on either vessel, and there was no pollution. There was no damage to the SILVER SPIRIT except minor paint scratches,  and very minor damages to the bulwark and rails of M/V SINAN ATASOY.  The claim for the damages of the owners of M/V SINAN ATASOY was settled locally at usd 12.000 in full and final  settlement including any loss of time for repairs.  The vessel then proceeded for discharging at Iskenderun, Turkey and afterwards for loading at Isdemir, Turkey without any delay.

On February 17th 2008 the bulk carrier JINSHAN left Noro Port en route to Taizhon, China. At 14.00 hours LT a breach in the hull was identified and water was found to be entering the 4th hatch. Emergency measures were taken, but to no effect. At approximately 23.00 hours LT the Master gave orders to abandon ship. The Master himself refused to abandon the ship and she sank at approimately 15.30 hours on 18th February 2008. The Master went missing and the Chief Engineer also went missing during evacuation and without bording the life boat.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
Between 04:20 and 04:50 on 18 February 2008, the United Kingdom registered cargo ship Sea Mithril grounded in the River Trent on three occasions. A river pilot was embarked and the visibility had reduced to about 20m by dense fog.

The groundings occurred after the ship had been manoeuvred by the master, to increase the passing distance from ship moored alongside at Flixborough. After touching the river bottom for the third time, Sea Mithril moored alongside Grove Warf at 05:10. There were no injuries to the crew and no pollution, but the ship sustained material damage to one of her azimuth propulsion pods.

THE PANAMANIAN CARGO SHIP "REZZAK" SAILED FROM NOVO TO BARTIN IN TURKEY ON 17.02.08 AT 00.55 HOURS LT BUT SHE DISAPPEARED IN THE BLACK SEA WITH 25 INDIAN CREW MEMBERS ON BOARD. HER LAST RECORDED POSITION WAS TAKEN FROM FLEET TRACKING AT 01.10 HOURS GMT LAT 42° 05.08' N  LONG 033° 52.44' E. TURKISH SEARCH AND RESCUE TEAMS RECOVERED NO BODIES AND NO TRACE OF THE SHIP, WHICH WAS ASSUMED TO HAVE SUNK WITH ALL CREW MISSING.

SOLASStatus: RIO BLANCO: SOLAS, RÍO BLANCO: SOLAS
Location: Vehicles Export Terminal, Port of Santos, Brazil
SummaryOfEvents:
On February 16th 2008 the Vehicles Carrier M/V Rio Blanco,  IMO Nr 8113994, flag Chilean, call sign CBRL, 18142 DWT, built November 1981, with 28 crew on board, suffered fire in Santos, Brazil  while docked at Vehicles Export Terminal, latitude 23°57'5" S and longitude 046°17'08"W. Three sailors died in the machine room, where the fire broke out. 
The «Rio Blanco» was taking on a cargo of automobiles and farm equipment when the blaze began. The Brazilian Marine Authority  investigated the cause of the fire, which could have been caused by a leak in a fuel pipe inside the machine room. 
The preliminary investigations undertaken by Harbors Captaincy naval inspectors of Santos Port pointed out  that at approximately17.35 hours on 16th February,  during the receipt of oil,  damage occurred in one of the fuel system's intermediary valves located in the ship's machines room. During attempts to repair the valve a heavy oil leak occurred directly on the auxiliary motor discharge nº 1, which began the fire.
The crew could not contain the fire and the Fire Department's assistance was requested. Firefighters extinguished the flames shortly after dawn on February  17th.
In accordance with the Resolution A.849(20) Code for the Investigation of Marine Casualties and Incidents  devices, the Chilean Navy sent experts to the port city of Santos to begin a joint investigation of the accident with Brazil's Navy. Brazil took the role of lead investigating State.

Because of the fire, everything on the ship was sompletely switched off. The ship Rio Blanco was transferred by tugboats from Vehicles Export Terminal on March 2nd to the wharf in front of the warehouses 33 and 34, in Right Margin of Santos Port. 
Despite mechanical and electrical problems that prevent the vessel's propulsion, the cargo carrier buoyancy was not affected. The ship was unfit to proceed trip.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship rendered unfit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents:
The 3 GT fishing ship Anette Brogger was en route to the home port Bonnerup Strand after having finished fishing around Hirtshals. The ship was together with another fishing ship, Karin, and in both ship only the skipper was on board. The two ship were sailing close to each other. They did not carry any catch but only the nets. Right after having passed the Svitringen  Rende Light in Kattegat, Anette Brogger suddenly disappear from the sight of Karin.

Karin’s kipper raised alarm and approximately one hour later a helicopter discovered a raft container, which was lying just below the sea surface. When the divers arrived it became clear that the raft was hold by Anette Brogger, on the bottom in a dept of approx. 10m.

Later the divers found the skipper dead in the wheel house.

Anette Brogger was raised on 10 April and set ashore in Grena

ON 13/02/2008 ABOUT 21.00 HOURS LT AN ELECTRICAL FIRE OCCURRED IN THE ENGINE ROOM OF THE BULK CARRIER "VANCOUVER VICTORY", LEAVING NO ELECTRICAL POWER ON BOARD. THE MASTER STARTED THE EMERGENCY GENERATOR TO FIGHT THE FIRE, BUT AFTER THE FIRE WAS EXTINGUISHED THE EMERGENCY GENERATOR ALSO BROKE DOWN. IT WAS DISCOVERED THAT THE GMDSS BATTERY WAS NOT FULLY FUNCTIONING EITHER,  SO THE VESSEL COULD ONLY COMMUNICATE BY VHF RADIO. THE FIRST REPORT OF THE FIRE WAS RECEIVED FROM THE VESSEL "YAMATO GAWA" AT 23.00 HOURS LT,  WHICH CONFIRMED THAT ALL THE GENERATORS WERE BADLY DAMAGED AND THE "VANCOUVER VICTORY" WAS DRIFTING WITHOUT ANY POWER.
EVENTUALLY SHE STARTED DRIFTING TOWARDS P. RONDO ISLAND AND MANAGEMENT TRIED TO ARRANGE A TUG TO ASSIST, AS WELL AS REQUESTING MANY PASSING  SHIPS TO TOW THE VESSEL CLEAR OF THE ISLAND. THE ONLY RESPONSE WAS FROM THE M/V "ISABELLA" WHO AT 04.20 HOURS ON 15TH FEBRUARY TOOK THE MOORING ROPE FROM THE "VANCOUVER VICTORY" AND TRIED TO TOW HER, BUT THE ROPE BROKE.
FINALLY, AT 05.30 HOURS LT ON 15TH FEBRUARY  THE VESSEL RAN AGROUND IN  POSITION 06º04.3N LOG 095º0655E, IN SHALLOW WATER OFF P. PONDO ISLAND. THERE WAS NO POLLUTION AS A RESULT OF THE GROUNDING.

On 7th January 2008, the oil tanker BREAKTHROUGH sailed from China en route to Nigeria, on its delivery voyage.
After experiencing difficulties with running the main engine on heavy fuel oil, the ship anchored off Cocos Island on 11th February 2008, seeking clean diesel oil bunkers to return to Indonesia for more fuel and spare parts. The weather deteriorated, causing the ship's anchor to drag. The ship grounded at about 15.45 hours LT on 12th February 2008. The steering gear was damaged by the grounding.

ON 11TH FEBRUARY 2008 THE CONTAINER SHIP "MSC SERENA"VESSEL GROUNDED AT CHAPMPLIN WITH PILOT ONBOARD AT APPROXIMATELY 23.25 HOURS LT. THE GROUNDING OCCURRED WHEN THE VESSEL TEMPORARILY LOST POWER. THE GENERATORS HAD TRIPPED DUE TO  LOOSE WIRING ON THE COOLING WATER PUMP. POWER WAS RESTORED AFTER ABOUT 5 MINUTES, THE VESSEL WAITED FOR THE TIDE TO RISE AND REFLOATED UNDER ITS OWN POWER. THE VESSEL HAD GROUNDED ON SOFT MUD AND THERE WAS NO LOSS OF LIFE, POLLUTION OR DAMAGE TO HULL AND MACHINERY.

On 6th February 2008 the ro-ro cargo ship Finnpine was approaching the port of Pointe au Pic, Canada. The pilot was using a self constructed leading line, which consisted of a lighted corner on the berth and a strong fixed light ashore. The leading line was not marked on the chart. About 740 meters from the berth the vessel stopped. The pilot and master, who were on the bridge,  thought it was due to the ice conditions in the area but shortly after they could confirm that the vessel had grounded. The grounding took place at around 06.00 LT, 3 hours before low water. At approximately 11.40 LT she re-floated and was put to anchorage outside Pointe au Pic for inspection.
The vessel was cleared to proceed to Les Mechins dry dock for temporary repairs.

Location: 13 miles away from the Rovinj city of Croatia
SummaryOfEvents:
Ro-Ro cargo ship UND ADRİYATİK departed Pendik/İstanbul for the port of Trieste/Italy on 03.02.2008 with 22 crew, 9 passengers and 202 trucks and vehicles (trailers). On 06.02.2008 several hours from arrival to the port of Trieste, the vessel had a fierce fire on board during her navigation in the waters of the North Adriatic Sea. The fire was noticed by the alarm of the automatic fire detection system at around 0535 (Turkish local time). A crew member was sent to the alarm scene and he noticed the fire on the trucks, which were parked inside the main deck. Accordingly, the general alarm was activated. Due to the alarm, the mustered crew attempted to fight the fire. However, due to the thick smoke and rapidly expanded flames, the crew failed to extinguish the fire. 

At 06:04 a Distress call was made from the vessel by VHF. The coastal stations immediately activated the rescue units upon receiving the Distress call.

The fire spread to all cargo spaces within a short time of 15-20 minutes. Firstly, it expanded at the aft side of the vessel. This situation blocked the passage to the life saving units for the crew who were mustered on the bridge and due to the risk of being trapped on the bridge all crew and passengers tried to escape to the fore part by sliding from the port wing using the ropes which were deployed at the bridge port wing side. During this action, 3 crew members and 2 passengers injured themselves by falling on to the top deck.

At the fore part, the crew waited for a while hoping the fire would not reach the forepart. However, due to the close flames, they disembarked the vessel by using the fore life raft.

Some of the crew entered into the life raft which was designed for 6 persons, the others waited in the sea around the liferaft. The passenger vessel IKARUS PALACE reached the scene and rescued the survivors at 08:06 and brought them to the port of Venice at noon. Fortunately, there were no casualties due to the good weather, sea condition and the immediate and comprehensive assistance of Croatian shore units.

The vessel burned for 2 days. Many tugs and fire extinguishing planes tried to extinguish the fire. They succeeded in extinguishing it on 08.02.2008 and cooling activities finished on 11.02.2008.

At the end of the fire the ship was totally burnt except for the ship’s engine room, pump room, steering gear, bowthruster room and emergency generator room, in other words all machinery spaces. All cargo, ro-ro decks, accomodation and cabins became unrecognizable. The top ro-ro deck melted and collapsed down, the ship’s whole structure became deformed due to the high temperature. The engine room remained intact  except the damage of the smoke and some minor melting of plastics due to heat. The ship survived sinking due to the high performance of the ship salvage team. There were no casualties due to the grace of God and the bunker/oil tanks remained intact so no pollution occured. On  20.02.2008, the ship was towed to the port of Trieste.

Due to the non-operational condition of the ship; the owner declared the constructive total loss of the ship from the insurers on 21.02.2008 and this request was approaved by the insurers on 25.03.2008.

On February 4, 2008 at approximately 0638LT, the Liberian Flag container vessel, SAN CLEMENTE was involved in a collision with the Liberian cargo vessel, COMANDATE while anchored at Vung Tau, Vietnam . The COMANDATE was moving into the anchorage, and despite repeated attempts by the SAN CLEMENTE to contact the COMANDATE via radio as it veered close to the vessel, the COMANDATE collided with the starboard bow of the SAN CLEMENTE. As a result, the SAN CLEMENTE sustained severe damage to the front starboard hull. There were no injuries to the crew and no incident of pollution was reported.

At 04.30 hours LT on 4th February 2008 a fire broke out during a tanker lifting operation in the engine room of the m/v MAERSK MASTER. The fire could not be extinguished by means of portable extinguishers so actions were taken to engage the engine room water mist system and subsequently the CO2 system. After approximately 15 minutes the fire was under control. Shortly aferwards the vessel was towed to a nearby shipyard for inspection.

There were no casualties.

On 1st February 2008 the vessel (a dry general cargo vessel carrying a cargo of road salt) was on passage from Belfast to Inverness.  Soon after leaving Belfast the main engine temperatures started to steadily increase.   The oil pressure dropped and it was noticed that there was an increase in the engine oil level.

Tests of the oil confirmed that it had become water contaminated.  The problem was located on a cylinder head and water was seen to transfer to the head valve operating gear into the sump.  The Chief Engineer advised the captain to come immediately to anchor, but the harbour authorities objected because of the frequent fast ferry service.  The vessel was taken further out from the harbour, but the engineer became increasingly concerned about the oil contamination and firmly advised the master to anchor or else risk the engine being written off.  By now the vessel was about 3.5 cables from a pipeline - the captain decided that it was safe to anchor.  After doing so the engineers removed the affected cylinder head and found blanking and locating screws loose.  The cylinder head had been subjected to the manufacturer's overhaul and had only been fitted 2 weeks previously.

While the repairs were being undertaken SOSREP was informed and decided that in light of the weather conditions and the potential risk to the pipeline,  the vessel should be towed into Belfast.  The vessel arrived alongside about 7 hours later.  Repairs were completed by the crew while alongside, and the oil change completed.

After treatment, all made good recoveries, and the vessel proceeded to Falmouth to carry out heavy weather repairs.

On the evening of 31st Jan 2008 the RoRo Freight vessel Riverdance was on passage from Warrenpoint to Heysham. The weather throughout the day had been strong Westerly gale force winds, increasing in strength. At the time of the initial incident winds force 10 were experienced along with large sea / swells.
Although the passage had been easy, with sea and swell coming from astern, as Riverdance approached the Lune Deep buoy she began to roll. Initially two trailers were reported to have shifted before the rolling died down. As the trailer shift was being investigated the rolling started again, stronger than before and resulting in cargo shifting from the trailers. A list of 45 deg to port was experienced and the master decided to bring the vessel head to wind. He applied full starboard wheel and the vessel turned rapidly, thus increasing the angle of heel. As the vessel became broadside to the wind this also added to the total heeling effect and a maximum list/heel of 60 deg was reported.
The vessel turned from a heading of 090 to 170 in 70 seconds. She then lost one of her two engines due to lube oil low pressure trip and would not come any closer to the wind. At this time the master contacted the Coast Guard.
Attempts to restart the engine were made and to transfer ballast to bring her upright. During this time Riverdance drifted towards the Shell Flat sands off the coast near Blackpool. Around 2300 hrs UTC she grounded on Shell Flat on a falling tide.
Initially 14 persons were evacuated by helicopter leaving 9 onboard attempting to stabilise the situation. Whilst aground the list decresed to about 25 deg. Ballast was transfered ready for coming off on the next rising tide in the morning. 
Once the vessel was starting to refloat the engines were put astern in an attempt to bring her into deeper water, the wind and seas were still storm force from the West and the engines had no effect. After about two hours, attempts to re float the vessel were stopped, Riverdance then came broadside to the weather and sufferred a sudden severe heeling over to starboard. The remaining crew were taken off the vessel and Riverdance was left aground with a heel of about 40 deg.
Subsequent attempts to refloat and salvage the vessel failed.

On 23rd January 2008 a fire broke out in one of the containers stowed on board the M/V WESTFALIA EXPRESS.  The Chief Officer raised the alarm at 19.50 hours LT, the crew were mustered, the deck lights switched on, the electrical supplies to the reefers were isolated and the fire pumps were started. The ship's speed was also reduced to dead slow ahead and her course was adjusted to reduce the wind over the deck. Four crew members fought the fire with sea water from hoses. Boundary cooling was also established. About 15 minutes after the fire was discovered, one of the containers exploded. Its door opened and its cargo of a white powder substance started to spill onto a hatch cover. Twenty minutes later, the fire was extinguished although heavy smoke continued to pour from the containers. About 12 hours after the fire, small holes were made in the containers most affected, which were then flooded via the insertion of hose nozzles. Boundary cooling continued. The door of one container emitting heavy smoke was opened and the fire inside was extinguished using four hoses. By the following morning (32 hours after detection), the containers had stopped smoking. 
The fire had started spontaneously in an open top container carrying a dangerous cargo class 4.2. The cargo, which is believed to have spilled and spontaneously combusted, was carried in 2 small tanks approx 1m in size.  A number of containers were damaged by fire. Some were flooded by water which accumulated in the hold during the fire-fighting operation. Others were also water-damaged.

In preparation to shoot nets, a 36 metre fishing vessel opened the fish net hatch, the hatch from the upper deck into the accommodation alleyway, the hatch from the upper deck to the main deck and the weathertight door between the accommodation alleyway and main deck. This allowed the crew unrestricted movement between the upper and main deck during fishing operations. The weather was described as moderate to rough and the vessel was steaming on beam seas.
The vessel was struck by a large wave which heeled her over to starboard. She was starting to return to the upright when she was hit by another wave and the vessel took on a permanent list due to the amount of sea water on her main deck net space and starboard accommodation alleyway. The list increased as water continued to wash over the vessel’s submerged starboard gunwale in way of an open net hatch and was able to progressively flood the engine room and aft accommodation via the weathertight door which had been left open. Although the crew attempted to close the net hatch on the upper deck, this did not stem the flow of water into the hull and the vessel started to sink.

Le second entreprend aussitôt une manœuvre de récupération d'homme à la mer. Le matelot perd rapidement connaissance et est hissé à bord avec difficulté.

Malgré les soins prodigués par le mécanicien puis par l'équipe médicale acheminée par hélicoptère, il décède environ une heure et demi plus tard.

SummaryOfEvents:

On 7 January 2008, the UK registered and managed, Anglo-Spanish fishing vessel, SHARK, left La Coruňa in northern Spain for fishing grounds off the west coast of Ireland.  The skipper had served on board for about 1 year, but for many of the 15 crew this was their first trip in the vessel.  
At about 20.00 hours on 18 January the long-line was shot away.  The crew then rested in their cabins until they were called at 01.00 hours LT to recover it.  At about 06.30 hours LT on 19 January 2008 , thick black smoke was seen coming from one of the crew’s cabins, but the smoke detection system alarm had not sounded.  Some of the crew attempted to fight the fire but they were quickly beaten back as the thick, acrid smoke quickly spread through the accommodation area.  Although a number of watertight doors were left open near to the fire, containment was established.     Four of the crew suffered smoke inhalation.
The skipper asked a nearby Spanish fishing vessel to stand by in case they had to abandon the vessel. 
The main fire pump could not be started because the electrical control circuits had been destroyed.  The emergency manual fire pump was defective, so there was no pressurised water supply with which to fight the fire.  As the paint on the main deck started to blister, the skipper attempted to starve the fire of oxygen, but he was hampered by faulty ventilation isolating valves, and had to stuff rags around the ventilation terminals.  The rags were later removed, and the fire re-ignited. At 12.31 hours LT the skipper finally alerted the Maritime Rescue Co-ordination Centre (MRCC) at Madrid, 6 hours after the fire had started.  Emergency service support was quickly provided.  The Irish Naval vessel, LE Eithne, arrived on the scene and transferred a fire party, who extinguished the fires.  SHARK was then escorted into Killibegs for inspection.
The fire caused extensive damage throughout the accommodation area.  The investigation found numerous examples of private electrical equipment connected to the cabin supplies, and electrical cables were found to be chafed where they passed over the rough edges of the cabin bulkheads.  The fire was probably of electrical origin, caused by a faulty supply cable.  The fire detection system had been intentionally disabled, and much of the emergency equipment was in poor condition.  SHARK was also out of date for her Maritime and Coastguard Agency (MCA) Intermediate Survey.  None of the crew had the required mandatory safety course certificates, the skipper did not hold the required Certificate of Equivalent Competency and no emergency training drills had been carried out.

Le Dimanche 06 Janvier 2008 aux environs de 17:30 heures, le chalutier « La p'tite Julie 1 » appareille du port d’Erquy pour ses lieux de pêche, situés dans le Nord de l’île d’Ouessant, avec sept personnes à bord.

A 04:46 heures le 07 Janvier ; le patron appelle le CROSS Corsen en VHF pour signaler qu’il est en train de couler. Il peut donner sa position et le nombre de personnes à bord. 
A 04:50 heures, le patron du chalutier Anthémis entre en communication en MF avec le patron de la « La p'tite Julie 1 », du même armement, qui lui précise que le bateau fait route, qu’il a une voie d’eau en train de couler par l’avant.
A 04:52 heures, après un dernier appel au CROSS Corsen en VHF, les sept membres de l’équipage sautent à la mer sans avoir pu enfiler les combinaisons de survie  ni percuter un radeau de sauvetage. 

A 07:31 heures, un hélicoptère récupère un survivant  en état d’hypothermie. Deux corps seront retrouvés dans la journée et les quatre hommes restants portés disparus.

Deux investigations sous-marines seront effectuées dans les jours suivants pour localiser  et identifier l’épave,  puis une investigation sera effectuée en juin 2008 par ROV. Elles ont pu montrer que la coque ne présentait pas  de trace de brèche ou de choc extérieur ; le panneau de débarque du poisson, sur le pont supérieur à l’avant de la timonerie, a été  trouvé ouvert avec des déformations.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
On the evening of 5th January 2008 the m/v HIGH HARMONY was en route from the port of Bandar Abbas, bound for Vadinar, India. On 6th January 2008 at 07.30 hours LT, the Master of M/v High Harmony was informed by the 3rd officer that Chief Cook Mr Sequeira had not reported for duty that morning. A search was carried out on board by ship staff, but Mr. Sequeira could not be located.
AB Mr. Anton Fernando had last seen the cook on the morning of the 6th January at about 05.30 hours LT, outside his cabin. The vessel was swung around to retrace its course until it arrived at the last known position when the cook had been seen. The vessel searched the waters for about five hours but could not locate any  trace of the missing Chief Cook.
After consultation with the Management Office the Master abandoned the search and resumed passage to original destination of Vadinar.

At approximately 21.00 hous LT on 5th January 2008 the Liberian Flag container ship CMA CGM IGUACU sustained main engine failure anda small fire in the main switchboard. While transiting the North Sea from Le Havre (en route to Brazil), the vessel sustained a total loss of power. Upon further examination it was discovered that the main switchboard of the vessel had sustained a short circuit, damaging two panels of the main switchboard. The vessel was subsequently towed to Brest, France, for repairs, and resumed her voyage to Brazil on 12th Janury 2008. 
Flag State investigation was conducted by obtaining the flag state report and follow-up communications for clarification after review as necessary.

Location: Near Gangavaram Port, East coast of India
SummaryOfEvents: At aproximately 16.27 hours LT on 3rd January 2008 the m/v ZHEN HUA 22 ran aground outside Gangavaram port dredged channel, whilst making her approach to the port entrance for berthing at the iron ore berth. The vessel sustained damage to her bottom shell. Class carried otu the damage survey.

On 3rd January 2008 the M/V VANESSA, loaded with 937.4t steel billets and 2007.6t wire rods coils was in the Sea of Azov, en route from Port of Berdyansk, Ukraine to Kerch Strait when she suffered structural failure, presumably hull cracks. At the time the sea was very rough, with adverse weather conditions: wind ENE 18-23 m/sec., with air minus 9 degrees centigrade. At 00.05 hours the Master reported to Kerch Traffic Control that the bulwark (port side) was totally torn from the ship and had fallen overboard. Within two hours the ship lost its residual buoyancy, and at 02.01 hours LT the Master transmitted a distress message. The Master, seven crew members and the Pilot all lost their lives. Since the accident occurred the ship has sunk further into the sea bed.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: ON 2ND JANUARY 2008 THE M/V "SUN VENUS" EXPERIENCED MAIN ENGINE PROBLEMS AND AT APPROXIMATELY 15.55 HOURS LT REPORTED THAT SHE WAS ADRIFT APPROXIMATELY 100 MILES SOUTH OF THE ISLAND OF OAHU.

Location: Varne Bank in the English Channel
SummaryOfEvents: At 04:50 hours on 2 January 2008, the LT Cortesia ran aground on the Varne Bank sandlank in the English Channel. The ship was on route from Thames Port to the Suez Canal. At the peak of the evening high tide, at 18:58 hours, the grounded ship was freed with the aid of four tug boats. For investigation purposes, the ship was ordered to proceed to a sheltered anchorage on the coast cast approximately 10 nm northeast of Dover. No major damage as a result of the grounding was identified, which meant that the LT Cortesia upped anchor and was able to continue on its voyage at 18:00 hours on 3 January 2008.

On 1st January 2008 the m/v OCEAN LADY sank off the Spanish/North African enclave of Ceuta. The sinking occurred just hours after the vessel had been towed out of the port on fire. The OCEAN LADY had been in the port for months and had become a refuge for illegal immigrants. Police believe the tug was purposely set alight in protest at regular raids on the vessel, and was towed into the strait of Gibraltar where rescue services tackled the blaze. Despite their efforts, the tug sank in deep water eight miles off Ceuta.
